revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name=Ada Kourí Barreto |image= Aankomst Raul Roa op Schiphol Raul Roa , zijn vrouw op vliegtuigtrap, Bestanddeelnr 912-5560.jpg |caption= Ada Kouri & Raúl Roa (1961) |birth_date=May 26, 1917 |birth_place=Havana, Cuba |death_date={{d-da|July 11, 2005|May 16, 1917}}|death_place=Rome, Italy }} Dr. '''Ada Kouri Barreto''' (May 26, 1917 in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] – July 11, 2005 in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]) was an eminent [[cardiologist]]. She was the wife of the [[Foreign relations of Cuba|Foreign Minister of Cuba]], [[Raúl Roa García]], and mother to the Cuban diplomat, [[Raúl Roa Kouri]].
Kouri was the eldest daughter of seven children of the prominent surgeon and Professor of Medicine at the University of Havana, Dr. [[Juan Bautista Kouri Esmeja]] and Dr. [[Josefina Barreto]]. Her siblings were Josefina, Marta Alicia, Silvia Margarita, Juan, Julio and Nejhie Kouri-Barreto.
As a young woman she was a militant of the Student Left Wing (Ala Izquierda Estudiantil) and after the March 1935 strike she joined her husband in exile in New York. After March 10, 1952, she took part in the anti-Batista movement as a physician, caring for clandestine combatants and other tasks of Civic Resistance.
During the first years of the Revolution she was the director of the Hygiene Institute. An eminent cardiologist, she was a founder in the field where she worked tirelessly until the age of 75. A member of the [[Federation of Cuban Women]] ''Federación de Mujeres Cubanas'' (FMC), the [[Milicias Nacionales Revolucionarias]] and [[Comités de Defensa de la Revolución]] (CDR).
She died in Rome where she was accompanying her son Raúl Roa Kouri at the Cuban Embassy to the [[Holy See]], victim of a cardiac-respiratory arrest at the age of 88.
==References== * [http://www.ain.cu/2005/julio/13cmfallecio.htm Agencia Cubana de Noticias obituary] {{es icon}} {{Portal|Cuba}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kouri Barreto, Ada}} [[Category:Cuban communists]] [[Category:Cuban revolutionaries]] [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:2005 deaths]] [[Category:People from Havana]] [[Category:People of the Cuban Revolution]]

{{Infobox person | name = Agénor de Gasparin | image = Agénor de Gasparin.jpg |birth_date = July 12, 1810 |death_date = May 4, 1871 |birth_place = [[Orange, Vaucluse]] |death_place = [[Geneva]] | occupation = Statesman, psychical researcher, writer}}
'''Agénor Étienne, comte de Gasparin''' (12 July 1810 - 4 May 1871) was a French [[politician|statesman]] and author. He was also an early [[Parapsychology|psychical researcher]] known for conducting experiments into [[table-tipping]].
==Biography==
He was born at [[Orange, Vaucluse]], the son of [[Adrien de Gasparin]]. In 1836 he entered the service of his father, then [[Minister of the Interior (France)|minister of the interior]], as chief of a department, became master of requests in the Council of State in 1837, and in 1842 was elected to the Chamber of Deputies from [[Bastia]] in [[Corsica]]. He was an advocate of religious liberty, prison reform, abolition of slavery, and the rights of the [[Protestant]] church, of which he was a member. His independence was not relished by the government, and his sympathy for Protestantism was not shared by his constituents. He was thus voted out of office in 1846, and put all of his enthusiasm into his written work.
When the [[French Revolution of 1848|revolution of 1848]] took place, he was asked to declare himself in favor of the new constitution. He refused. His disapproval of the form later given to the government by [[Napoleon III|Louis Napoleon]] was even stronger, and he permanently moved to [[Switzerland]].
From 1849 until his death, he lived at [[Geneva]]. In the winter, he delivered courses of lectures on economical, historical, and religious subjects, many of which were subsequently published. During the [[Franco-German War]] he addressed an appeal to the French people urging them not to persevere in it. His death was hastened by his exertions in the care of refugees from [[Charles Denis Bourbaki|Bourbaki]]'s army, whom he received into his house.
==Spiritualism==
In 1853, Gasparin with a group of his friends conducted experiments into [[table-tipping]] at his home. The experiments were conducted over a period of five months. He recorded the activity of table movements which he believed were the result of a physical force emanating from the bodies of the sitters. He proposed a theory of fluidic action (termed "ectenic force"), which he believed could explain the phenomena.<ref>Anderson, Rodger. (2006). ''Psychics, Sensitives and Somnambules: A Biographical Dictionary with Bibliographies''. McFarland & Company. pp. 68-69. {{ISBN|978-0786427703}}</ref>
Professor Marc Thury (1822-1905) from the [[University of Geneva]] who also attended some of the experiments supported Gasparin's conclusions in a pamphlet in 1855,<ref>[[Frank Podmore|Podmore, Frank]]. (1897). [https://archive.org/stream/studiesinpsychic00podm#page/44/mode/2up ''Studies in Psychical Research'']. New York: Putnam. p. 44</ref> and conducted some of his own experiments in which similar results were obtained.<ref>[[Hereward Carrington|Carrington, Hereward]]. (2007, originally published 1939). ''Laboratory Investigations into Psychic Phenomena''. Whitefish, MT: Kessinger Publishing. p. 44</ref> The physicist and spiritualist [[William Crookes]] was influenced by Gasparin's experiments.<ref>[[William Crookes|Crookes, William]]. (1874). [https://archive.org/stream/researchesinphe00croo#page/26/mode/2up ''Researches in the Phenomena of Spiritualism'']. London: James Burns. pp. 26-27</ref> The experiments were also endorsed by [[A. Campbell Holms]].<ref>[[A. Campbell Holms|Holms, A. Campbell]]. (1927). ''The Facts of Psychic Science and Philosophy''. Occult Press. pp. 276-277</ref>
[[Camille Flammarion]] provided summaries of the work of de Gasparin and Thury.<ref>[[Camille Flammarion|Flammarion, Camille]]. (1907). ''[https://archive.org/stream/mysteriouspsychi002803mbp#page/n281/mode/2up Mysterious Psychic Forces]''. Small, Maynard And Company. pp. 229-288</ref> Critics like [[Frank Podmore]] argued that the conditions were insufficient to prevent trickery.<ref>[[Frank Podmore|Podmore, Frank]]. (1897). [https://archive.org/stream/studiesinpsychic00podm#page/47/mode/2up ''Studies in Psychical Research'']. New York: Putnam. p. 47 "If neither the feet nor the hands of the sitters could be employed, the knees could apparently have been used without much risk, and Thury clearly could not watch both the upper and under surfaces simultaneously. On the whole, though the experiments were conducted with care and a laudable desire not to exaggerate the importance of the facts observed, the experimenters do not appear to have sufficiently realised the possibilities of fraud; and their results add little evidence for action of a psychic, or, as Thury has preferred to name it, ectenic force."</ref><ref>[[Hugh Chisholm|Chisholm, Hugh]]. (1911). ''The Encyclopaedia Britannica: A Dictionary of Arts, Sciences, Literature and General Information, Volumes 25-26''. New York. p. 337. "It is doubtful from the description of the experiments whether the precautions taken were sufficient to exclude unconscious muscular action or even deliberate fraud."</ref>
The table-tipping experiments were heavily criticized by [[Louis Figuier]]. He noted that Gasperin's claim of the movement of tables without material contact was a "physical impossibility" and that he was never able to reproduce the phenomena before the French [[scientific community]]. He stated that "to admit reality of the elevation of a table, without any contact, it would have to be reproduced several times, and at will, in experiences with other observers. This has never arrived; which leads one to conclude that any [[connivance]] slipped into the experiments."<ref>[[Louis Figuier|Figuier, Louis]]. (1880). [https://archive.org/stream/b21498180_0002#page/579/mode/2up''Les Mystéres De La Science'']. Paris: Librairie Illustree. p. 579</ref>
==Works== He published numerous articles in the ''[[Journal des Débats]]'' and the ''[[Revue des Deux Mondes]]''. Among his books were:
On the separation of church and state: * ''Les intérêts généraux du protestantisme français'' (1843) * ''Christianisme et paganisme'' (Christianity and Paganism; 2 vols. 8vo, 1846) On the abolition of slavery: * ''Esclavage et traite'' (1838) * ''Un grand peuple qui se relève'', argues for the justice of the Union cause in the [[American Civil War]] (The Uprising of a Great People, 1861) * ''L'Amérique devant l'Europe'', another book advocating the Union cause (America Before Europe, 1862) On the reform of home life: * ''La famille, ses devoirs, ses joies et ses douleurs'' (2 vols. 12mo, 1865) * ''La liberté morale'' (1863) * ''La conscience'' (1872) * ''L'ennemi de la famille'' (1874) On the [[Franco-German War]]: * ''La déclaration de guerre, un protêt'' (1870) * ''La république neutre d'Alsace'' (1870) * ''Appel au patriotisme et au bon sens'' (1871) Other works: * ''De l'amortissement'' (1834) * [https://archive.org/details/lestablestourna00gaspgoog ''Des tables tournantes, du surnaturel en général et des esprits''] (2 vols. 12mo, 1854; translated into English) * ''La question du Neufchâtel'' (1857) * [https://archive.org/details/sciencevsmodern00bairgoog ''Science vs. modern spiritualism: A treatise on turning tables, the supernatural in general and spirits''] (1857) * ''Liberal Christianity'' (1869)
His biography of [[Pope Innocent III|Innocent III]], ''Vie d'Innocent III'', was published posthumously in 1873.
==Family== His wife, [[Valérie Boissier de Gasparin]], was a noted writer.
==References== {{Reflist}}
* {{Cite AmCyc|wstitle=Gasparin, Adrien Étienne Pierre, count de}} * {{NIE|wstitle=Gasparin, Agénor Etienne, Count de |year=1905}} * {{Americana|wstitle=Gasparin, Agénor Etienne, Comte de}}
==Further reading== * Naville, ''Le Comte Agénor de Gasparin'' (Geneva, 1871) * Théodore Borel, ''Le Comte Agénor de Gasparin'' (2d ed., Paris, 1879; Eng. trans. by [[Oliver O. Howard]], [https://archive.org/details/countagnordega00bore ''Count Agénor de Gasparin''], New York, G. P. Putnam's Sons, 1881) * Bar Fey-Boisier, ''La Comtesse Agnes de Gasparin et sa famille; correspondance et souvenirs, 1813-1894'' (2 vols., Paris, 1902)
==External links== {{Wikisource author}} * {{Gutenberg author | id=Gasparin,+Agénor,+comte+de | name=Agénor de Gasparin}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Agénor de Gasparin |sopt=w}}
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox NFL biography | name = Austin Carr | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | current_team = New Orleans Saints | number = 80 | position = [[Wide receiver]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1993|12|25}} | birth_place = [[Benicia, California]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 1 | weight_lbs = 195 | high_school = [[Benicia High School|Benicia]] ([[Benicia, California]]) | college = [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] | undraftedyear = 2017 | pastteams = * [[New England Patriots]] ({{NFL Year|2017}})* * [[New Orleans Saints]] ({{NFL Year|2017}}–present) | pastteamsnote = yes | status = Active | highlights = * Northwestern Captain (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insidenu.com/2016/8/26/12666084/northwestern-football-captains-2016-anthony-walker-matt-harris-austin-carr-connor-mahoney |title=Northwestern announces Austin Carr, Connor Mahoney, Matt Harris and Anthony Walker as captains |author=Ian McCafferty |date=August 26, 2016 |publisher=SB Nation |work=www.insidenu.com |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> * First Team All-Big Ten (2016) * 2016 Second All-American Team (USA Today, Sports Illustrated)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nusports.com/news/2016/12/8/football-austin-carr-named-sports-illustrated-second-team-all-american.aspx |title=Carr named Sports Illustrated Second Team All-American}}</ref> * 2016 Bulsworth Trophy Finalist * 2016 Biletnikoff Award Finalist |statweek=12 |statseason=2018 |statlabel1=[[Reception (American football)|Receptions]] |statvalue1=9 |statlabel2=[[Receiving yards]] |statvalue2=97 |statlabel3=[[Touchdown|Receiving touchdowns]] |statvalue3=2 | nflnew = austincarr/2558928 }}
'''Austin Durant Mozée Carr''' (born December 25, 1993) is an [[American football]] [[wide receiver]] for the [[New Orleans Saints]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He played [[college football]] at [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]].
==Personal life== In November of 2015, after registering with [[Be The Match]] two and a half years earlier, Carr was contacted that he may be a potential match to donate peripheral blood [[stem cells]]. Through a five hour procedure, he was able to donate his stem cells via [[Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation|a blood transfusion]], which ultimately saved the life of the recipient, a retired locomotive engineer for the Union-Pacific railroad who had [[non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=KAHLER |first1=KALYN |title=At the Super Bowl, a Saints Rookie Meets the Man Whose Life He Saved |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2018/02/02/super-bowl-52-austin-carr-saints-bone-marrow-donor |accessdate=20 September 2018 |publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=2 February 2018}}</ref>
==College career== A former walk-on at [[Northwestern University]],<ref>{{cite web |url=https://northwestern.rivals.com/news/nu-adds-nine-walkons |title=NU adds nine walkons |date=June 14, 2012 |publisher=Yahoo! |work=www.northwestern.rivals.com |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> Carr earned a scholarship and became a starter in his junior year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/college/ct-austin-carr-northwestern-football-spt-0920-20160919-story.html |title=Northwestern receiver Austin Carr is a beast in more ways than one |author=Teddy Greenstein |date=September 19, 2016 |publisher=Chicago Tribune |work=www.chicagotribune.com |accessdate=October 28, 2016}}</ref> In his senior year in 2016, Carr led the [[Big Ten Conference]] in receptions, receiving yards, and receiving touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bigten.org/library/stats/fb-confldrs.html#indiv|title=Big Ten Football Statistics|access-date=October 3, 2016}}</ref> Following the 2016 season, Carr was named the [[Big Ten Conference football individual awards#Richter–Howard Receiver of the Year|Richter–Howard Receiver of the Year]] and was named First Team All-Big Ten by the coaches and media.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/big10/sports/m-footbl/auto_pdf/2016-17/misc_non_event/16fbawardwinners.pdf |title=2016 Big Ten Individual Award Winners |date=November 30, 2016 |publisher=Big Ten Conference |work=www.grfx.cstv.com |accessdate=December 1, 2016}}</ref>
==Professional career== {{NFL predraft | height ft = 6 | height in = 0 | weight = 202 | dash = 4.62 | ten split = 1.60 | twenty split = 2.62 | shuttle = 4.07 | cone drill = 6.70 | vertical = 33 1/2 | broad ft = 9 | broad in = 8 | bench = 16 | wonderlic = | arm span = | hand span = | note = All values from [[2016 Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern’s Pro Day]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.draftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=1008403&draftyear=2017&genpos=wr |title=Austin Carr, DS #48 WR, Northwestern|work=DraftScout.com |access-date=November 10, 2018}}</ref> }} ===New England Patriots=== On April 30, 2017, the [[New England Patriots]] signed Carr as an [[undrafted free agent]] to a three-year, [[United States dollar|$]]1.67 million [[contract]] that includes a signing bonus of $7,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csnchicago.com/big-ten/northwestern-receiver-austin-carr-signs-patriots-undrafted-free-agent|title=Northwestern receiver Austin Carr signs with Patriots as Undrafted Free Agent |publisher=CSN Chicago|date=29 April 2017 |accessdate=30 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Patriots Sign Sixth-Round Draft Pick Conor McDermott; Sign 19 Rookie Free Agents|url=http://www.patriots.com/news/2017/05/05/patriots-sign-sixth-round-draft-pick-conor-mcdermott-sign-19-rookie-free-agents|website=Patriots.com|date=May 5, 2017|access-date=2017-05-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170512003817/http://www.patriots.com/news/2017/05/05/patriots-sign-sixth-round-draft-pick-conor-mcdermott-sign-19-rookie-free-agents|archive-date=2017-05-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Spotrac.com: Austin Carr contract |url=https://www.spotrac.com/nfl/new-orleans-saints/austin-carr-22292/ |accessdate=November 11, 2018 |website=Spotrac.com}}</ref>
Carr shined in the preseason, recording 14 catches for 153 yards and two touchdowns in the four games. Despite a strong training camp and preseason, Carr was waived by the Patriots on September 2, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Patriots reach 53-man limit|url=http://www.patriots.com/news/2017/09/02/patriots-reach-53-man-limit|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171128033226/http://www.patriots.com/news/2017/09/02/patriots-reach-53-man-limit|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 28, 2017|website=Patriots.com|date=September 2, 2017}}</ref>
===New Orleans Saints=== On September 3, 2017, Carr was claimed off waivers by the [[New Orleans Saints]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New Orleans Saints announce roster moves|url=http://www.neworleanssaints.com/news-and-events/article-1/New-Orleans-Saints-announce-roster-moves/b3ecc654-f060-4caf-a675-5a07a52f6ace|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180210104629/http://www.neworleanssaints.com/news-and-events/article-1/New-Orleans-Saints-announce-roster-moves/b3ecc654-f060-4caf-a675-5a07a52f6ace|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 10, 2018|website=NewOrleansSaints.com|date=September 5, 2017}}</ref> He was active for two games during his rookie season but did not catch any passes.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.nusports.com/roster.aspx?rp_id=4038 Northwestern profile]
{{New Orleans Saints roster navbox}}

{{About|the former Philippine president|other people of the same name|Benigno Aquino (disambiguation){{!}}Benigno Aquino}} {{pp-protected|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Philippine name|Cojuangco|Aquino}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Benigno Aquino III |image = File:Benigno Aquino III Offical 2015.jpg |office = [[List of Presidents of the Philippines|15th]] [[President of the Philippines]] |vicepresident = [[Jejomar Binay]] |term_start = June 30, 2010 |term_end = June 30, 2016 |predecessor = [[Gloria Macapagal Arroyo]] |successor = [[Rodrigo Duterte]] |office1 = [[Secretary of the Interior and Local Government (Philippines)|Secretary of the Interior and Local Government]]
{{small|Acting}} |term_start1 = June 30, 2010 |term_end1 = July 9, 2010 |predecessor1 = [[Ronaldo Puno]] |successor1 = [[Jesse Robredo]] |office2 = [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator of the Philippines]] |term_start2 = June 30, 2007 |term_end2 = June 30, 2010 |office3 = [[Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Philippines]] |term_start3 = November 8, 2004 |term_end3 = February 21, 2006 |predecessor3 = [[Raul M. Gonzalez|Raúl Gonzalez]] |successor3 = [[Simeon Datumanong|Simeón Datumanong]] |office4 = Member of the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines|Philippine House of Representatives]] from [[Legislative districts of Tarlac#2nd District|Tarlac]]'s [[Legislative districts of Tarlac|2nd]] District |term_start4 = June 30, 1998 |term_end4 = June 30, 2007 |predecessor4 = José Yap |successor4 = José Yap |birth_name = Benigno Simeón Cojuangco Aquino III |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|2|8}} |birth_place = [[Manila]], Philippines |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal]] |parents = [[Benigno Aquino Jr.]]
[[Corazon Aquino]] |relatives = See [[Aquino family]] |alma_mater = [[Ateneo de Manila University]] |signature = Nonoy Aquino Signature.svg |website = }} {{BenignoAquinoIIISegmentsUnderInfoBox}} '''Benigno Simeon''' '''"Noynoy"''' '''Cojuangco Aquino III'''{{cite web |url=http://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/sen_bio/aquino_noynoy_bio.asp |title=Senator Benigno S. Aquino III |publisher=Senate of the Philippines |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209034426/http://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/sen_bio/aquino_noynoy_bio.asp |archivedate=February 9, 2010 |df=mdy }}Quezon, Manuel L.. (June 19, 2010) [http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/insights/06/19/10/trivia-aquino-and-binay Trivia on Aquino and Binay]. ABS-CBN News. Retrieved on January 23, 2012. (born February 8, 1960 in [[Manila]]) is a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] politician who served as the [[List of Presidents of the Philippines|15th President of the Philippines]] from 2010 until 2016.{{cite web|title=Aquino promises justice as Philippines president – Yahoo! News|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100609/ap_on_re_as/as_philippines_aquino|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100615002143/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100609/ap_on_re_as/as_philippines_aquino|archivedate=June 15, 2010|date=June 9, 2010}}{{cite web|title=Congress final tallies|work=INQUIRER.net|url=http://politics.inquirer.net/politics/view/20100608-274547/Congress-final-tallies|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822205729/http://politics.inquirer.net/politics/view/20100608-274547/Congress-final-tallies|archivedate=August 22, 2010|date=June 8, 2010}} Aquino is a fourth-generation politician and the [[chairman]] of the Liberal Party from 2010 to 2016.{{cite web|title=Resume of Senator Aquino – Senate of the Philippines|url=http://www.senate.gov.ph/senators/sen_bio/aquino_noynoy_resume.asp|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614192915/http://senate.gov.ph/senators/sen_bio/aquino_noynoy_resume.asp|archivedate=June 14, 2010|df=mdy-all}} On September 9, 2009, shortly after the [[Death and funeral of Corazon Aquino|death of his mother]], Aquino officially announced he would be a candidate in the [[Philippine presidential election, 2010|2010 presidential election]]. He was elected and on June 30, 2010 was [[Inauguration of Benigno Aquino III|sworn into office]] as the [[List of Philippine Presidents#List of Presidents|fifteenth President of the Philippines]] at the [[Quirino Grandstand]] in [[Rizal Park]], Manila,[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/193465/news/nation/noynoy-aquino-to-take-oath-at-the-luneta-grandstand Noynoy Aquino to take oath at the Luneta grandstand | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (June 15, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012., succeeding [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]]. He stepped down at the end of his term on June 30, 2016, succeeded by [[Rodrigo Duterte]]. In 2013, ''[[Time Magazine|Time]]'' named him one of the [[Time 100|100 Most Influential People in the World]].{{cite news| url=http://time100.time.com/2013/04/18/time-100/slide/noynoy-aquino/|title=The 100 Most influential people in the world | work=Time | date=April 18, 2013}} In 2018 Aquino was indicted for budget misuse.{{cite news| url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/06/philippine-president-benigno-aquino-indicted-budget-misuse-180620084846137.html|title=Philippine ex-president Benigno Aquino indicted for budget misuse | work=Al Jazeera}} ==Early life and education== Benigno Simeon "Noynoy" Aquino III was born at 10:28 am on February 8, 1960 at [[Far Eastern University|Far Eastern University Hospital]] in [[Sampaloc, Manila]].{{cite web |url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-1-14066-40597-86?cc=1686086&wc=M8GZ-26X:129556201,130029101,155415301 |title=Philippines, Manila, Civil Registration, 1899-1994 Image Philippines, Manila, Civil Registration, 1899-1994; pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-1-14066-40597-86 — FamilySearch.org |accessdate=January 26, 2015}} He is the third of the five children of [[Benigno Aquino, Jr.|Benigno S. Aquino, Jr.]], who was then the Vice Governor of [[Tarlac]] province, and [[Corazon Aquino|Corazon Cojuangco]], daughter of a prominent Tarlac businessman. He has four sisters, namely: Maria Elena (Ballsy), Aurora Corazon (Pinky), Victoria Elisa (Viel), and [[Kris Aquino|Kristina Bernadette (Kris)]]. He attended [[Ateneo de Manila University]] in [[Quezon City]] for his elementary, high school, and college education.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/171863/news/nation/the-son-also-rises-who-is-noynoy-aquino The son also rises: Who is Noynoy Aquino? | GMA News Online ]. Gmanetwork.com (September 9, 2009). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Aquino finished his [[Bachelor of Arts]] (major in [[economics]]) from [[Ateneo de Manila University]] in 1981, He was one of the students of former professor of economics at Ateneo de Manila University, former President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]]. He joined his family in their exile in the [[United States]] shortly thereafter. He returned to the Philippines in 1983 shortly after the [[Assassination of Benigno Aquino, Jr.|assassination of his father]] and held several positions working in the private sector. In September 1972, Aquino's father, who was then a senator and prominent opposition leader to President [[Ferdinand Marcos]], was arrested for subversion. In August 1973, Aquino's father was brought before a military tribunal in [[Fort Bonifacio]].[http://www.pressreader.com/philippines/manila-times/20150208/281724087973756/TextView NINOY'S LETTER TO NOYNOY – The Manila Times via PresReader]. Retrieved March 9, 2016 In 1980, after a series of heart attacks, Aquino's father was allowed to seek medical treatment in the [[United States]], where Aquino's family began a period of self-exile. In 1981, shortly after graduation, Aquino joined his family in the United States. In 1983, after three years in exile in the United States, Aquino's family returned to the [[Philippines]], shortly after the [[Assassination of Benigno Aquino, Jr.|assassination of his father]] on August 21, 1983. He had a short tenure as a member of the [[Philippine Business for Social Progress]], working as an assistant of the executive director of PBSP. He later joined Mondragon Industries Philippines, Inc. as an assistant Retail Sales Supervisor and assistant promotions manager for [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] Philippines, Inc. From 1986 to 1992, during the presidency of his mother, Aquino joined the Intra-Strata Assurance Corporation, a company owned by his uncle Antolin Oreta Jr., as vice president. On August 28, 1987, eighteen months into the presidency of Aquino's mother, rebel soldiers led by [[Gregorio Honasan]] staged an [[1986–1987 Philippine coup attempts#August 1987 coup attempt|unsuccessful coup attempt]], attempting to lay siege to [[Malacañang Palace]]. Aquino was two blocks from the palace when he came under fire. Three of Aquino's four security escorts were killed, and the last was wounded protecting him. He himself was hit by five bullets, one of which is still embedded in his neck.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20070821-83752/Noynoy_Aquino_also_rises |title=Noynoy Aquino also rises |publisher=INQUIRER.net |date=August 21, 2007 |first=Dona |last=Pazzibugan}} From 1993 to 1998, he worked for Central Azucarera de Tarlac, the sugar refinery in the Cojuangco-owned [[Hacienda Luisita]]. He was employed as the executive assistant for administration from 1993 to 1996 and subsequently worked as manager for field services from 1996 to 1998. In 1998, he was elected to the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines|House of Representatives]] as Representative of the 2nd district of [[Tarlac]] province. He was subsequently re-elected to the House in 2001 and 2004. In 2007, having been barred from running for re-election to the House due to [[term limits]], he was elected to the Senate in the [[14th Congress of the Philippines]]. ==Congressional career== Aquino is a fourth-generation politician: his great-grandfather, [[Servillano Aquino|Servillano "Mianong" Aquino]], served as a [[delegate]] to the [[Revolutionary Government of the Philippines|Malolos Congress]]; his paternal grandfather, [[Benigno Aquino, Sr.]], served as [[Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Philippines]] from 1943 to 1944; his maternal grandfather, [[Jose Cojuangco]], was also a member of the House of Representatives; and his parents were [[Corazon Aquino]], who served as the 11th President of the Philippines (1986–92), and Senator [[Benigno Aquino, Jr.|Benigno "Ninoy" Aquino, Jr.]] Aquino is a member of the [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal Party]],[http://abs-cbnnews.com/nation/09/01/09/noynoy-poised-run-president 'Noynoy' poised to run for president]. ABS-CBN News. Retrieved on January 23, 2012. where he held various positions such as Secretary General and Vice President for [[Luzon]]. ===House of Representatives (1998–2007)=== Aquino became [[House of Representatives of the Philippines|Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives]] on November 8, 2004, but relinquished the post on February 21, 2006, when Aquino joined his [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal Party]] members in calling for the resignation of President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] at the height of the [[Hello Garci scandal]]. Aquino was also [[Chairman of the Board]] of the Central Luzon Congressional Caucus. ===Senate (2007–10)=== Barred from running for re-election to the [[House of Representatives of the Philippines]], to represent the [[Legislative districts of Tarlac|2nd district of Tarlac]], due to [[term limits]], Aquino was elected to the [[Senate of the Philippines]] in the [[Philippine general election, 2007|2007 Philippine midterm election]] on May 15, 2007, under the banner of the [[Genuine Opposition]] (GO), a coalition comprising a number of parties, including Aquino's own [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal Party]], seeking to curb attempts by President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] to amend the [[Constitution of the Philippines|1986 Philippine Constitution]]. In Aquino's political ads, he was endorsed by his younger sister, TV host [[Kris Aquino]], and his mother, the late former President Corazon Aquino. Although a [[Roman Catholic]], Aquino was endorsed by the [[pentecostal]] [[Jesus Is Lord Church]], one of the largest [[Protestantism|Protestant]] churches in the Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/40912/news/nation/11-days-to-e-day-elections-for-sale |title=11 days to E-Day |publisher=GMANews.TV |date=May 3, 2007 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/40819/news/nation/jil-backs-loren-noynoy-koko-kiko-in-senate-race|title=JIL backs Loren, Noynoy, Koko, Kiko in Senate race |publisher=GMANews.TV |date=May 3, 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=75867 |title=Brother Eddie Villanueva endorses 3 more GO bets |date=May 3, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070926224349/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=75867 |archivedate=September 26, 2007 }} With more than {{Nowrap|14.3 million}} votes, Aquino's tally was the sixth highest of the 37 candidates for the 12 vacant seats elected from the nation at large. Aquino assumed his new office on June 30, 2007. During the campaign, Aquino reached out to his former enemy, Senator [[Gregorio Honasan]], supporting his application for bail. Aquino told Job Tabada of Cebu Daily News, on March 5, 2007; {{quote|"I endorse Honasan's request for bail ''para parehas ang laban'' [to even out the playing field]. I was hit by bullets from Honasan's men in the neck and hips but that's past now. The principle of my father was, 'Respect the rights even of your enemies.' ''Ito ang nagpatingkad ng demokrasya'' [This is what defines democracy]. Genuine reconciliation is democracy in action."{{cite news|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/cebudailynews/opinion/view/20070305-52984/Reconcile_this|title=Reconcile this|last=Tabada|first=Job|date=March 5, 2007|work=Cebu Daily News|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822210022/http://globalnation.inquirer.net/cebudailynews/opinion/view/20070305-52984/Reconcile_this|archivedate=August 22, 2010|df=mdy-all}}}} Aquino was referring to an unsuccessful coup attempt staged by rebel soldiers led by Gregorio Honasan on August 28, 1987, in which Aquino was seriously injured. {{POV|date=March 2012}} ====Senate bills==== {{BLP sources section|date=April 2016}} The Budget Impoundment and Control Act (SB 3121), wherein "impoundment" refers to the power of the president to refuse the release of funds appropriated by the [[Congress of the Philippines]], is another bill Aquino is proud of;from an interview with freelance writer Lila Shahani for ''Philippines Graphic'', later posted on the writer's blog as [http://lilashahani.blogspot.com/2010/03/conversation-with-noynoy.html "A Conversation with Noynoy"] (March 2010){{Unreliable source?|date=April 2016}} he regretted, however, that such power has been used and abused by President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]], a result of which abuse has been the significant emasculation of Congress' ability to check the president's authority. Aquino filed this bill so the president would have to pass through Congress every time the president decides to impound part of the budget. Another significant Aquino contribution to the Philippines' corruption problem was Senate Bill 2035, which is the ''Preservation of Public Infrastructures'' bill, seeking to raise standards in the construction of all public infrastructures by penalizing contractors of defective infrastructures. The bill also requires the Bureau of Maintenance under the [[Department of Public Works and Highways]] to conduct periodic inspections of public infrastructures. Aquino also pushed for the passage of the Amending the Government Procurement Act (SB 2160), which applies to all government procurement activities regardless of source of funds whether local or foreign; only treaties or international/executive agreements entered into by the government prior to its enactment shall be exempt from coverage. The bill was filed in light of the [[Department of Justice (Philippines)|Department of Justice]] declaration regarding the validity of the controversial [[NBN-ZTE scandal]], wherein its international aspect, as well as the fact that it was an executive agreement, was cited as one reason for its exemption from the procurement process stipulated in Republic Act 9184. Focusing further on accountability in government appropriations and spending, Aquino filed other reform-oriented bills, among which were [[Philippine National Police]] reform; an increase in penalties for corporations and work establishments not compliant with minimum wage; the banning of reappointment to the [[Judicial and Bar Council]]; the prevention of reappointment and bypassing of the [[Commission on Appointments]]; real property valuation based on international standards; and superior responsibility for senior military officers, who are ultimately responsible for their own subordinates. However, none of these bills were passed into law. ==2010 presidential campaign== {{Main article|Philippine presidential election, 2010}} {{See also|Benigno Aquino III presidential campaign, 2010}} [[File:Presidentelectaquino.jpg|thumb|right|Aquino being proclaimed as the [[President of the Philippines|President-elect of the Philippines]] by [[President of the Senate of the Philippines]] [[Juan Ponce Enrile]] and [[Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Philippines|House Speaker]] [[Prospero Nograles]] at the [[Batasang Pambansa Complex|Batasang Pambansa]] in [[Quezon City]] on June 9, 2010.]] [[File:Map of dignitaries who attend the Aquino's inauguration.PNG|thumbnail|Map of dignitaries who attend Aquino's inauguration.]] On November 26, 2008, the [[Liberal Party (Philippines)|Liberal Party]] elected [[Mar Roxas]], president of the Liberal Party, as the standard-bearer of the Liberal Party for [[President of the Philippines]] in the then-upcoming [[Philippine presidential election, 2010|2010 presidential elections]].{{cite web |title=Roxas is new LP President |url=http://www.mb.com.ph/node/48863 |publisher=[[Manila Bulletin]] |date=November 27, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607201533/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/48863 |archivedate=June 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Following the [[Death and funeral of Corazon Aquino|death and funeral of Aquino's mother]], former President Corazon Aquino, many people began calling on Aquino to run for [[President of the Philippines]].{{cite web|title=Official Program Aquino Inaugural (Excerpts)|url=https://www.scribd.com/mlq3/d/33654204-Official-Program-Aquino-Inaugural-Excerpts|access-date=September 8, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212173824/https://www.scribd.com/mlq3/d/33654204-Official-Program-Aquino-Inaugural-Excerpts|archive-date=February 12, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} This groundswell of support became known as the "Noynoy Phenomenon".{{cite web |url=http://the-diplomat.com/philippines-election-2010/candidate-profiles/ |title=Candidate Profiles: Benigno Simeon 'Noynoy' Cojuangco Aquino III |publisher=The-diplomat.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412115449/http://the-diplomat.com/philippines-election-2010/candidate-profiles/ |archivedate=April 12, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} On August 27, 2009, Edgardo "Eddie" Roces, son of the late [[Chino Roces]], former publisher and owner of ''[[The Manila Times]]'', and a group of lawyers and activists formed the Noynoy Aquino for President Movement (NAPM), a nationwide campaign to collect a million signatures in order to persuade Aquino to run for president,{{cite web|title='Noynoy for President' signature drive launched | work=ABS-CBN News |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/08/27/09/noynoy-president-signature-drive-launched|date=August 27, 2009}} reminiscent of Roces' father, who on October 15, 1985, launched the Cory Aquino for President Movement (CAPM), collecting more than one million signatures nationwide, asking Aquino's mother to run against Ferdinand Marcos in the [[Philippine presidential election, 1986|1986 presidential snap elections]].{{cite web|title=About – Noy Aquino for President Movement|url=http://www.noyaquino2010.com/about|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816034647/http://noyaquino2010.com/about/|archivedate=August 16, 2011|df=mdy-all}} In September 2009, the Liberal Party held numerous press conferences in relation to the [[Philippine general election, 2010|2010 elections]] at the [[Club Filipino]] in Greenhills, [[San Juan, Metro Manila|San Juan]], the site of the presidential inauguration of Aquino's mother in February 1986. On September 1, 2009, at the [[Club Filipino]], in a press conference, Senator [[Mar Roxas]], president of the Liberal Party, announced his withdrawal from the 2010 presidential race and expressed his support for Aquino, as the party standard-bearer instead.[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20090901-223047/Roxas-throws-support-for-Aquino-in-2010 Roxas throws support for Aquino in 2010 – INQUIRER.net, Philippine News for Filipinos] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904195544/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20090901-223047/Roxas-throws-support-for-Aquino-in-2010 |date=September 4, 2009 }}. Newsinfo.inquirer.net. Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Aquino later stood side by side with Roxas, but did not make a public statement at the press conference. The next day, Aquino announced that he would be going on a "spiritual retreat" over the weekend to finalize his decision for the elections, visiting the [[Carmelites|Carmelite sisters]] in [[Zamboanga City]]. reminiscent of his mother's own soul-searching in 1985 before deciding to run for the elections the following year.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/171333/news/nation/noynoy-to-go-on-retreat-before-baring-2010-plans Noynoy to go on 'retreat' before baring 2010 plans | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (September 2, 2009). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. He came back on September 9 to formally announce his candidacy.{{cite web |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20090909-224337/Noynoy-Aquino-to-run-for-president-in-2010 |title=Aquino declares presidential bid |publisher=INQUIRER.net |first=Maila |last=Ager |date=September 9, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206073432/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20090909-224337/Noynoy-Aquino-to-run-for-president-in-2010 |archivedate=February 6, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} Almost two weeks later, Roxas pledged to run alongside Aquino as the Liberal Party standard-bearer for vice-president.[http://www.internetphilippines.com/news/mar-roxas-accepts-vice-president-run-in-2010/ Mar Roxas Declares Vice Presidency Bid]. internetphilippines.com (September 22, 2009){{cite web|title=Liberal Party launches Aquino-Roxas tandem for 2010 |work=Sun.Star |url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/network/now-official-roxas-aquino%E2%80%99s-veep |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091226075650/http://www.sunstar.com.ph/network/now-official-roxas-aquino%E2%80%99s-veep |archivedate=December 26, 2009 }} The two men filed their respective certificates of candidacy for [[President of the Philippines|president]] and [[Vice President of the Philippines|vice-president]] on November 28, 2009. Fake [[psychological evaluation|psychiatric reports]] on Aquino's [[mental health]] began circulating online during the 90-day election campaign period from February 9 – May 8, 2010,{{cite web|title=Campaign period ends at midnight; liquor ban on|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=573347&publicationSubCategoryId=63|date=May 8, 2010}}[http://www.filamnation.com/article.php?article_id=11750 FilAmNation's article – Noynoy shrugs off black propaganda]. FilAmNation (April 29, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Aquino received information that the first such report came from the wife of [[Nacionalista Party]] supporter and former [[National Power Corporation]] (NAPOCOR) president Guido Delgado, a move Aquino claims was made with "malicious intent". A second report came from an unidentified supporter of [[Senate of the Philippines|Senator]] [[Manny Villar]], the Nacionalistas' leader and presidential candidate.{{cite web|title=Villar supporter presents Aquino’s ‘psychiatric report’|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100427-266735/Villar-supporter-presents-Aquinos-psychiatric-report|date=April 27, 2010|work=inquirer.net|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100430090716/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/metro/view/20100427-266735/Villar-supporter-presents-Aquinos-psychiatric-report|archivedate=April 30, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Later presented by Delgado at a press conference, the psychiatric report was supposedly signed by Father Jaime C. Bulatao, S.J., PhD, a [[Jesuit]] priest, a professor of [[Psychology]] and a [[clinical psychologist]] at the [[Ateneo de Manila University]], taken when Aquino was finishing his [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[economics]] at the university in 1979. It reportedly showed that Aquino suffered from [[Depression (mood)|depression]] and [[melancholia]], the priest later denied writing the document at all. Another supposed psychiatric report that later surfaced claimed that Aquino suffered from [[major depressive disorder]]; the report's supposed author, Jesuit priest Father Carmelo A. Caluag II, denied writing any evaluations of Aquino. The university's psychology department later debunked the documents, with Aquino labelling them as another desperate effort by rivals to malign his reputation. [[File:2010PhilippinePresidentialElection (simple).png|left|thumb|194px|
2010 Philippine electoral vote results
]] During the campaign, Senator [[Francis Escudero]] began endorsing Aquino as president and [[Partido Demokratiko Pilipino-Lakas ng Bayan|PDP-Laban]] standard-bearer [[Jejomar Binay]], for [[Vice President of the Philippines|Vice President]], launching the [[Aquino-Binay Campaign, 2010|Aquino-Binay campaign]].{{cite web |url=http://politics.inquirer.net/politics/view/20100428-266945/Escudero-distributes-Noybi-stickers-and-shirts|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822204814/http://politics.inquirer.net/politics/view/20100428-266945/Escudero-distributes-Noybi-stickers-and-shirts|archivedate=August 22, 2010|date=April 28, 2010 |title=Escudero distributes ‘Noybi’ stickers and shirts|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer|Inquirer.net]]}} However, this was done without the consent of the two candidates; Binay was former President [[Joseph Estrada]]'s running mate for vice-president. During the [[Philippine presidential election, 2010|2010 presidential election]], held on May 10, 2010, in [[Philippine presidential election, 2010#Unofficial tallies|unofficial tallies]], conducted by the [[Commission on Elections]] (COMELEC) and the Parish Pastoral Council for Responsible Voting (PPCRV), Aquino was the leading candidate in tallied votes for president, and in the [[Philippine presidential election, 2010#Official Congressional canvass|official Congressional canvass]], Aquino was the leading candidate in canvassed votes for president.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/192045/news/nation/congress-starts-canvassing-with-overseas-vote-first-in-line Congress starts canvassing with overseas vote first in line | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (May 27, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Aquino was unofficially being referred to as "president-apparent" by the media.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/192393/news/specialreports/president-apparent-aquino-sounds-like-royalty President-apparent Aquino? Sounds like royalty | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (June 1, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. On June 9, 2010, at the [[Batasang Pambansa Complex]], in [[Quezon City]], the [[Congress of the Philippines]] proclaimed Aquino as the [[President of the Philippines|President-elect of the Philippines]], following the [[Philippine presidential election, 2010|2010 election]] with 15,208,678 votes, while [[Jejomar Binay]], the former mayor of [[Makati City]], was proclaimed as the [[Vice President of the Philippines|Vice President-elect of the Philippines]] with 14,645,574 votes,{{cite web|title=Final tally: Binay leads Roxas by 700,000 votes | work=ABS-CBN News |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/06/08/10/final-tally-binay-leads-roxas-700000-votes|date=August 6, 2010}} defeating [[runner-up]] for the vice presidency Mar Roxas, the standard-bearer of the Liberal Party for vice president. ==Presidency (2010–2016)== {{Main article|Presidency of Benigno Aquino III}} {{See also|List of presidential trips made by Benigno Aquino III|Noynoying}} {{Infobox President styles |name=Benigno S. Aquino III |image = [[File:Seal of the President of the Philippines.svg|50px]] |dipstyle= [[Excellency|His Excellency]] |offstyle= Your Excellency |altstyle= Mr. President }} [[File:Inauguration of Benigno Aquino III.jpg|270px|thumbnail|right|Benigno Aquino III takes the oath of office as the 15th President of the Philippines before Associate Justice [[Conchita Carpio-Morales]] at the Quirino Grandstand on June 30, 2010.]] The '''Presidency of Benigno S. Aquino III''' began at noon on June 30, 2010, when he became the [[List of Philippine Presidents#List of Presidents|fifteenth]] [[President of the Philippines]], succeeding [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]]. Since the start of his presidency, he has also been referred to in the media as '''PNoy'''.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/202080/news/nation/back-from-us-pnoy-says-43k-jobs-to-be-generated-in-3-years Back from US, PNoy says 43K jobs to be generated in 3 years | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (September 28, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. The [[Presidential transition of Benigno Aquino III|presidential transition]] began on June 9, 2010, when the [[Congress of the Philippines]] proclaimed Aquino the winner of the [[Philippine presidential election, 2010|2010 Philippine presidential elections]] held on May 10, 2010, proclaiming Aquino as the [[President of the Philippines|President-elect of the Philippines]]. The transition was in charge of the new presidential residence, cabinet appointments and cordial meetings between them and the [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo|outgoing administration]]. [[File:President Aquino at work.jpg|thumb|left|President Aquino at work]] The presidential residence of Aquino is ''Bahay Pangarap'' ([[English language|English]]: House of Dreams),[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/06/09/10/bahay-pangarap-aquinos-future-home Bahay Pangarap: Aquino's future home?]. ABS-CBN News. Retrieved on January 23, 2012. located inside of Malacañang Park, at the headquarters of the [[Presidential Security Group]] across the [[Pasig River]] from [[Malacañang Palace]].[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=588969&publicationSubCategoryId=63 Noynoy's new home is Bahay Pangarap – The Philippine Star " News " Headlines]. Philstar.com (June 30, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Aquino is the first president to make ''Bahay Pangarap'' his official residence.{{cite web|title=Briefer on Bahay Pangarap and Malacañang Park|url=http://www.gov.ph/2010/07/29/briefer-on-bahay-pangarap-and-malacanang-park/|work=The Official Gazette. Presidential Communications Development and Strategic Planning Office|date=July 29, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712075540/http://www.gov.ph/2010/07/29/briefer-on-bahay-pangarap-and-malacanang-park/|archivedate=July 12, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Malacañang Park was intended as a recreational retreat by former President [[Manuel L. Quezon]]. The house was built and designed by architect Juan Arellano in the 1930s, and underwent a number of renovations. In 2008, the house was demolished and rebuilt in contemporary style by architect Conrad Onglao, a new swimming pool was built, replacing the Commonwealth-era swimming pool.[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=597999&publicationSubCategoryId=63 Bahay Pangarap for P-Noy ready – The Philippine Star " News " Headlines]. Philstar.com (July 30, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. The house originally had one bedroom, however, the house was renovated for Aquino to have four bedrooms, a guest room, a room for Aquino's household staff, and a room for Aquino's close-in security.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/197976/news/nation/how-was-pnoy-s-first-night-at-bahay-pangarap How was PNoy’s first night at Bahay Pangarap? | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (August 6, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. The house was originally intended as a rest house, the venue for informal activities and social functions for the First Family by former President [[Manuel L. Quezon]]. Malacañang Park was refurbished through the efforts of First Lady [[Eva Macapagal]], wife of former President [[Diosdado Macapagal]], in the early 1960s. First Lady Macapagal renamed the rest house as ''Bahay Pangarap''. During the [[presidency of Fidel V. Ramos]], the house was restored and became the club house of the Malacañang Golf Club. The house was used by former President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] to welcome special guests. Aquino refused to live in [[Malacañang Palace]], the [[official residence]] of the [[President of the Philippines]], or in Arlegui Mansion, the residence of former presidents Corazon Aquino and [[Fidel V. Ramos]], stating that the two residences are too big, and also stated that his small family residence at Times Street in Quezon City would be impractical, since it would be a security concern for his neighbors. [[File:President Aquino with Ambassador Thomas.jpg|thumb|left|[[Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs]] [[William Joseph Burns]] (middle) shakes hands with [[President of the Philippines|President]] Benigno S. Aquino III (right) as [[United States Ambassador to the Philippines]] [[Harry K. Thomas, Jr.]] (left) looks on.]] On June 29, 2010, Aquino officially named the members of his Cabinet, with Aquino himself as [[Department of the Interior and Local Government (Philippines)|Secretary of the Interior and Local Government]],{{cite web |url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100629-278220/Aquino-names-Cabinet-takes-DILG-helm |title=Aquino names Cabinet, takes DILG helm |publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=June 29, 2010 |first=Maila |last=Ager |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100630172447/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100629-278220/Aquino-names-Cabinet-takes-DILG-helm |archivedate=June 30, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} a position that [[Vice President of the Philippines|Vice President-elect]] [[Jejomar Binay]] initially wanted; however, Aquino stated that the post was not being considered for him.{{cite web|url=http://politics.inquirer.net/politics/view/20100623-277169/Binay-meets-Aquino-declines-Cabinet-post|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100629180520/http://politics.inquirer.net/politics/view/20100623-277169/Binay-meets-Aquino-declines-Cabinet-post|archivedate=June 29, 2010|title=Binay meets Aquino, declines Cabinet post|publisher=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=June 23, 2010|first=Maila |last=Ager}} He instead offered Binay various positions, such as head of a commission to investigate the outgoing Arroyo administration, the posts of [[Department of Agrarian Reform (Philippines)|Secretary of Agrarian Reform]], [[chairman]] of the Housing and Urban Development Coordinating Council (HUDCC), and the chairman of [[Metropolitan Manila Development Authority]] (MMDA), but Binay refused.{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/06/24/10/binay-offered-new-office-probe-arroyo|title=Binay offered new office to probe Arroyo|publisher=[[ABS-CBN]] News|date=June 24, 2010}} Aquino also announced the formation of a [[truth commission]] that will investigate various issues including corruption allegations against outgoing President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]]. Aquino named former [[Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines|Chief Justice]] [[Hilario Davide, Jr.]] to head the [[truth commission]].[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100629-278225/Davide-named-Truth-Commission-chief Davide named Truth Commission chief] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100630172636/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100629-278225/Davide-named-Truth-Commission-chief |date=June 30, 2010 }}. INQUIRER.net (June 29, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Traditionally, it is the [[Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines]] who administers the [[oath of office]] to the incoming [[President of the Philippines|president]] and [[Vice President of the Philippines|vice president]], however, Aquino refused to allow [[Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines|Chief Justice]] [[Renato Corona]] to swear him into office, due to Aquino's opposition to the midnight appointment of Corona by outgoing President [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] on May 12, 2010, two days after the [[Philippine general election, 2010|2010 elections]] and a month before Arroyo's term expired.{{cite web|title=No Corona-tion for Noynoy|work=INQUIRER.net|url=http://globalnation.inquirer.net/columns/columns/view/20100524-271792/No-Corona-tion-for-Noynoy|date=May 24, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210031347/http://globalnation.inquirer.net/columns/columns/view/20100524-271792/No-Corona-tion-for-Noynoy|archivedate=February 10, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Instead, Aquino formally requested [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines]] [[Conchita Carpio-Morales]], who opposed the midnight appointment of Corona,[http://sc.judiciary.gov.ph/jurisprudence/2010/march2010/191002_carpio-morales.htm G.R. No. 191002]. Sc.judiciary.gov.ph. Retrieved on January 23, 2012. to swear him into office.{{cite web|title=Lady justice to administer Aquino oath|work=INQUIRER.net|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20100619-276377/Lady-justice-to-administer-Aquino-oath|date=June 19, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012214457/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20100619-276377/Lady-justice-to-administer-Aquino-oath|archivedate=October 12, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Aquino took the [[Inauguration of Benigno Aquino III|oath of office]] on June 30, 2010, at the [[Quirino Grandstand]] in [[Rizal Park]], [[Manila]]. The oath of office was administered by [[Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines|Associate Justice]] [[Conchita Carpio-Morales]], who officially accepted Aquino's request to swear him into office, reminiscent of the decision of his mother, who in 1986, was sworn into the presidency by Associate Justice [[Claudio Teehankee]]. After being sworn in as the [[List of Philippine Presidents#List of Presidents|fifteenth]] [[President of the Philippines]], succeeding [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]], Aquino delivered his [[s:Benigno Aquino III's Inaugural Address|inaugural address]]. During the inaugural address, Aquino created the "no ''[[wang-wang]]''" policy, strengthening the implementation of [http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/presdecs/pd1973/pd_96_1973.html Presidential Decree No. 96].Pedrasa, Ira. (July 20, 2010) [http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/-depth/07/20/10/p-noy%E2%80%99s-%E2%80%98wang-wang%E2%80%99-policy-sets-culture-change P. Noy’s ‘wang-wang’ policy sets culture change]. ABS-CBN News. Retrieved on January 23, 2012.[http://www.mb.com.ph/node/265632/mmda- MMDA sees positive effect of 'wang-wang' confiscation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712212444/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/265632/mmda- |date=July 12, 2010 }}. The Manila Bulletin Newspaper Online (July 7, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. The term ''‘wang-wang’'' is street lingo for blaring sirens.Erik Espina [http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/267945/take-two-no-wangwang Take Two: ‘No wang-wang’] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723143456/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/267945/take-two-no-wangwang |date=July 23, 2010 }}. The Manila Bulletin Newspaper Online (July 20, 2010) Presidential Decree No. 96 was issued on January 13, 1973 by former [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Ferdinand Marcos]], regulating the use of sirens, bells, whistles, horns and other similar devices only to motor vehicles designated for the use of the [[President of the Philippines|president]], [[Vice President of the Philippines|vice president]], [[President of the Senate of the Philippines|senate president]], [[Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Philippines|House Speaker]], [[Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the Philippines|chief justice]], [[Philippine National Police]], [[Armed Forces of the Philippines]], [[National Bureau of Investigation (Philippines)|National Bureau of Investigation]], [[Land Transportation Office (Philippines)|Land Transportation Office]], Bureau of Fire Protection and [[ambulances]]. However, despite having the privilege of using ''‘wang-wang’'', Aquino maintained he would set the example for his no ''‘wang-wang’'' policy, not to use ''‘wang-wang’'', even if it means being stuck in traffic and being late every now and then.[http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20100703-278888/No-wangwang-no-limo-Aquino-stuck-in-traffic No ‘wangwang,’ no limo, Aquino stuck in traffic] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705133054/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/inquirerheadlines/nation/view/20100703-278888/No-wangwang-no-limo-Aquino-stuck-in-traffic |date=July 5, 2010 }}. INQUIRER.net (June 9, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012.[http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=591315&publicationSubCategoryId=63 P-Noy late again, but no wang-wang policy stays – The Philippine Star " News " Headlines]. Philstar.com (July 8, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. Aquino also traded the official black presidential [[Mercedes Guardian|Mercedes Benz S-Guard]] limousine for his own white [[Toyota Land Cruiser#200 Series|Toyota Land Cruiser 200]]. After the inaugural address, the [[Metropolitan Manila Development Authority]] began to enforce Aquino's no ''‘wang-wang’'' policy, confiscating ''‘wang-wang’'' from public officials and private motorists who illegally used them. On July 26, 2010, at the [[Batasang Pambansa]], in [[Quezon City]], Aquino delivered his [[s:Benigno Aquino III's First State of the Nation Address|first State of the Nation Address]] (SONA).[http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/267438/pnoy-s-first-sona-awaited P-Noy’s first SONA awaited] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722060816/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/267438/pnoy-s-first-sona-awaited |date=July 22, 2010 }}. The Manila Bulletin Newspaper Online (July 23, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/197030/news/nation/sona-english-translation-of-pres-benigno-s-aquino-iii-s-state-of-the-nation-address SONA: English translation of Pres. Benigno S. Aquino III's State of the Nation Address | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (July 26, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. During Aquino's first [[State of the Nation Address (Philippines)|State of the Nation Address]] (SONA), Aquino announced his intention to reform the [[education in the Philippines|education system in the Philippines]] by shifting to [[K–12 education]], a 12-year basic education cycle.[http://lcc.deped.gov.ph/lcc/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=231:education-in-the-sona&catid=35:news&Itemid=64 Education in the SONA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819213753/http://lcc.deped.gov.ph/lcc/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=231%3Aeducation-in-the-sona&catid=35%3Anews&Itemid=64 |date=August 19, 2011 }}. Lcc.deped.gov.ph (July 29, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. K–12 education is used in the [[United States]], [[Canada]], and [[Australia]]. On July 29, 2015, Aquino delivered his [[2015 State of the Nation Address (Philippines)|final SONA address]], where he discussed the country's economic improvements and the benefits of social service programs, particularly the [[Pantawid Pamilyang Pilipino Program]] and the [[Philippine Health Insurance Corporation]], during the course of his presidency.{{cite news|last1=Sabillo|first1=Kristine Angeli|title=2-hour Sona on Aquino gains strewn with swipes at Binay|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/708275/2-hour-sona-on-aquino-gains-strewn-with-swipe-at-binay|accessdate=January 16, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=July 27, 2015}} [[File:President Obama with President Aquino.jpg|thumb|[[United States]] President [[Barack Obama]], with President Aquino and [[Vietnam]]ese President [[Nguyễn Minh Triết]], at a working lunch with leaders of the [[Association of Southeast Asian Nations]] around the [[United Nations General Assembly]] Meeting in [[New York City]] in 2010.]] [[File:President Benigno Aquino III with U.S Secretary of State Hillary Clinton.jpg|thumb|[[United States Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] delivers remarks at the [[Millennium Challenge Corporation]] (MCC) compact agreement signing ceremony with [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Benigno S. Aquino III]] at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]] in [[New York City]], on September 23, 2010.]] [[File:Pope Francis Malacanang 51.jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|President Aquino and [[Pope Francis]] at Malacañang on [[Pope Francis' visit to the Philippines|January 16, 2015]].]] [[File:Barack Obama and Benigno Aquino III 4.28.14.jpg|thumb|left|President Aquino meeting with U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], at the Malacañang Palace upon his state visit to Manila, 2014.]] [[File:Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko of Japan during their arrival at the Malacañan Palace for the State Dinner 012716.jpg|thumb|left|President Aquino with Japanese Emperor [[Akihito]] and Empress [[Empress Michiko of Japan|Michiko]] on January 27, 2016.]] ===Criticisms=== ====Manila hostage crisis==== On August 23, 2010, in front of the [[Quirino Grandstand]] in [[Rizal Park]], [[Manila]], the site of Aquino's presidential inauguration, the [[Manila hostage crisis]] occurred. Aquino expressed concern over the matter and gave his condolences to the victims. Aquino defended the actions of the police at the scene, stating that the gunman had not shown any signs of wanting to kill the hostages. Aquino ordered a "thorough investigation" into the incident, and would wait until it is completed before deciding whether anyone should lose his or her job.{{cite news|title=Hong Kong warns against Philippines travel after deaths|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11067310 | work=BBC News | date=August 24, 2010}} Aquino declared that the media may have worsened the situation by giving the gunman "a bird's-eye view of the entire situation".{{cite news|title=Gunman in the Philippines ends standoff by killing 8, wounding 7|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/08/23/philippines.bus.hostages/index.html?hpt=T1#fbid=Zn5zrYu1rwk&wom=true | work=CNN | date=August 24, 2010}} Aquino also made reference to the [[Moscow theater hostage crisis]], which, according to Aquino, resulted in "more severe" casualties despite Russia's "resources and sophistication".[http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/273922/aquino-explains-his-stand-mondays-hostage-crisis Aquino explains his stand on Monday's hostage crisis] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100827130039/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/273922/aquino-explains-his-stand-mondays-hostage-crisis |date=August 27, 2010 }}. The Manila Bulletin Newspaper Online (August 24, 2010) On August 24, 2010, Aquino signed [http://www.gov.ph/2010/08/24/proclamation-no-23/ Proclamation No. 23], declaring August 25, 2010, as a national day of mourning, instructing all public institutions nationwide and all Philippine embassies and consulates overseas to lower the [[Philippine flag]] at [[half-mast]], in honor of the eight [[Hong Kong residents]] who died in the crisis.[http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/273993/noynoy-declares-august-25-natl-day-mourning Noynoy declares August 25 as Nat'l Day of Mourning] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609050947/http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/273993/noynoy-declares-august-25-natl-day-mourning |date=June 9, 2011 }}. The Manila Bulletin Newspaper Online (August 24, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/199308/news/nation/national-day-of-mourning-declared-for-slain-hostages National Day of Mourning declared for slain hostages | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com (August 24, 2010). Retrieved on January 23, 2012. On August 25, 2010, at a press conference in Malacañang, Aquino apologized to those offended when he was caught on television apparently smiling while being interviewed at the crime scene hours after the [[Manila hostage crisis]].Ager, Maila (August 25, 2010) [https://web.archive.org/web/20130728124640/http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20100825-288733/Aquino-says-sorry-for-the-smile Aquino says sorry for the ‘smile’]. inquirer.net Aquino said; {{quote|"My smile might have been misunderstood. I have several expressions. I smile when I'm happy, I smile when I'm faced with a very absurd situation...and if I offended certain people, I apologize to them. It's more of an expression maybe of exasperation rather than anything and again, I apologize if I offended certain people, who misunderstood (my) facial expression."}} On September 3, 2010, Aquino took responsibility for the crisis.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110613165101/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/nation/09/03/10/aquino-takes-responsibility-bus-siege-tragedy Aquino takes responsibility for bus siege tragedy]. ABS-CBN News (September 3, 2010) Aquino actually has direct supervision of the [[Philippine National Police]], since Aquino had asked [[Department of the Interior and Local Government (Philippines)|Secretary of the Interior and Local Government]] [[Jesse Robredo]] to address other concerns, such as coming up with a comprehensive plan on delivering social services to and relocating informal settlers in coordination with the local governments. ====Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda)==== President Aquino's administration was criticised during and after [[Typhoon Haiyan|Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda)]] in November 2013 for the government's "slow" response to aid the victims.[http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/352359/news/nation/after-4-months-pnoy-apologizes-for-slow-govt-response-to-yolanda-victims After 4 months, PNoy apologizes for slow govt response to Yolanda victims | News | GMA News Online]. Gmanetwork.com. Retrieved on March 17, 2016. This criticism resulted in countries like [[Canada]] to provide humanitarian aid to the victims of the typhoon through [[non-governmental organization]]s and not the Philippine government, wherein the Canadian Ambassador to the Philippines, Neil Reeder cited "the speed, because of the need to move quickly, and because we don’t, as a government, want to be involved in the details, nor do we think it’s efficient to have other governments involved."{{cite news|last1=Esmaquel|first1=Paterno II|title=‘Family ties’ push Canada to give more Yolanda aid|url=http://www.rappler.com/nation/119013-canada-philippines-yolanda-haiyan-donations|accessdate=January 16, 2016|work=[[Rappler]]|date=January 14, 2016}} ====Mamasapano massacre==== President Aquino was accused of evading responsibility for the death of 44 [[Special Action Force]] operatives in a failed operation, which led to the so-called [[Mamasapano massacre]].[http://philnews.ph/2015/03/25/pres-aquino-trying-to-evade-liability-mamasapano-incident-sen-santiago/ Pres. Aquino Trying to Evade Liability in Mamasapano Incident According to Sen. Santiago]. Philnews.ph (March 25, 2015). Retrieved on 2016-03-17. ====Noynoying==== ''Noynoying'' (pronounced noy-noy-YING{{cite news| title=Planking is out, 'Noynoying' is in| date=March 16, 2012| author=Jaymee T. Gamil and Julie M. Aurelio| publisher=Philippine Daily Inquirer| url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/162279/planking-is-out-%E2%80%98noynoying%E2%80%99-is-in}} or noy-NOY-ying{{cite news| title=Foreign media get wind of "noynoying"| date=March 21, 2012| publisher=ABS-CBN News| url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/video/-depth/03/21/12/foreign-media-get-wind-noynoying| accessdate=March 26, 2012}}) is a protest tactic in the form of a [[neologism]] that Aquino's critics have used to question his work ethic, alleging his inaction on the issues of disaster response and rising oil prices. A play on the term [[planking (fad)|planking]] and Aquino's nickname, Noynoying involves posing in a lazy manner, such as sitting idly while resting his head on one hand, and doing nothing. {{Main article|Noynoying}} ===Cabinet=== {{see also|Cabinet of the Philippines}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! '''Title''' ! '''Name''' ! '''Term''' |- ||[[President of the Philippines|President]] || [[Benigno S. Aquino III]] || 2010–2016 |- ||[[Vice President of the Philippines|Vice President]] || [[Jejomar Binay]] || 2010–2016 |- |Cabinet Secretary ||[[Jose Rene Almendras]]|| 2012–2016 |- |[[Executive Secretary (Philippines)|Executive Secretary]] ||[[Paquito Ochoa, Jr.]] || 2010–2016 |- |[[Presidential Communications Group (Philippines)|Press Secretary]]||[[Edwin Lacierda]]||2010–2016 |- |[[Department of Agrarian Reform (Philippines)|Secretary of Agrarian Reform]]||[[Virgilio de los Reyes]]||2010–2016 |- |[[Department of Agriculture (Philippines)|Secretary of Agriculture]]||[[Proceso Alcala]]||2010–2016 |- |[[Department of Budget and Management (Philippines)|Secretary of Budget and Management]]||[[Florencio Abad]]||2010–2016 |- |[[Department of Education (Philippines)|Secretary of Education]]||Br.
