revision.comment: removed [[Category:People associated with computer security]]; added [[Category:Computer security specialists]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
'''Christopher Abad''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]], [[museum]] [[curator]], [[artist]], network engineer and [[programmer]]. He is best known for his qualitative analysis of specialization stratification in the underground economies related to [[computer crime]].
==Academic publication and mainstream news coverage== While at [[UCLA]], Abad discovered a method by which collisions in the [[hash function]] used in [[Internet Protocol]] datagrams may be leveraged to enable [[covert]] channel communications.<ref name="hash_coll">{{Citation | last = Abad | first = Christopher | author-link = | publication-date = | date = | year = 2001 | title = IP Checksum Covert Channels and Selected Hash Collision | periodical = | series = | publication-place = | place = | publisher = | volume = | issue = | pages = 3 | at = | format=PDF | url = http://www.gray-world.net/papers/ipccc.pdf | accessdate = 2010-10-08 }}</ref> His discovery was a centerpiece of covert communications methodology and was the primary citation for an [[Association for Computing Machinery]] paper on covert channel detection<ref name="acm1">{{cite journal |citeseerx=10.1.1.84.6196 }}</ref> and another on a similar technique using [[Transmission Control Protocol|TCP]] [[timestamp]]s,<ref name="acm2">{{cite journal |citeseerx=10.1.1.104.2501 }}</ref> the two most well-cited and widely republished papers on the subject.
In 2005 while working at Cloudmark, Abad spent six months examining the phishing underworld from the inside.<ref name="onlinewsj1">{{cite news |title=Phisher Tales: How Webs of Scammers Pull Off Internet Fraud |first=Lee |last=Gomes |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=2005-06-20 |url=https://www.wsj.com/public/article/SB111922540322063658-k2iziFe2OaO0z3gRtu_AvHbEtKk_20060620.html |accessdate=2010-10-08}}</ref> Abad discovered that phishers were using [[IRC]] channels in order to trade personal information.<ref name="infomationweek1">{{cite news |title=Researcher Describes How The Phishing Economy Works |first=Gregg |last=Keizer |newspaper=[[InformationWeek]] |date=2005-07-29 |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/security/vulnerabilities/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=166403892 |accessdate=2010-10-08}}</ref> He stalked and collected messages from thirteen chat rooms phishers use.<ref name="infomationweek1"/> Whereas past phishing researchers believed that phishing was coordinated by highly organized criminals, Abad discovered that phishing rings were decentralized.<ref name="infomationweek1"/> Abad published his findings in [[First Monday (journal)|First Monday]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=2005 |title=The economy of phishing: A survey of the operations of the phishing market |journal=[[First Monday (journal)|First Monday]] |publisher= |volume=10 |issue=9 |pages= |url=http://firstmonday.org/htbin/cgiwrap/bin/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1272/1192 |doi= }}</ref> This paper was the first examination of how the economy of [[phishing]] agents functioned, and highlighted the high degree of specialization within the economy.
==20 GOTO 10== Abad is the founder and owner<ref name=lee>Lee, Ellen. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/01/12/BUBFUD235.DTL Early computer-generated art revived for S.F. exhibit]. ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''. 12 Jan 2008.</ref> of [[20 GOTO 10]], a former gallery which caters not only to [[fine art]], but to "[[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]]" art, with an emphasis on [[technology]] as art, or exhibits which make the potentially criminal or unethical aspects of computer security accessible to the public.<ref>McMillan, Robert ([[International Data Group|IDG]] News service)[http://www.itworld.com/Tech/2987/071030hackerart/ San Francisco gallery shows hacker Joe Grand's work as art] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080303153851/http://www.itworld.com/Tech/2987/071030hackerart/ |date=March 3, 2008 }} [https://www.pcworld.com/article/138991/san_francisco_gallery_shows_hackers_work_as_art.html 2] ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'', ''[[IT World]]''</ref> The gallery received many favorable reviews coverage for its airing of art related to the computer underground, including [[ANSI]]<ref>Johnson, Joel. [http://gadgets.boingboing.net/2008/01/28/ansi-art-show-at-20.html ANSI Art Show at 20 GOTO 10 Gallery] ''[[Boing Boing]]''. 28 Jan 2008.</ref> and [[Stereoscopy|3D]]<ref>Hart, Hugh. [https://www.wired.com/underwire/2008/07/art-geek-create/ Art Geek Creates 3-D on a Shoestring]''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. 9 Jul 2008.</ref> art.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{About|the politician|the sportscaster|Dan Patrick|other uses|Dan Patrick (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Dan Patrick | image = Lt Governor Dan Patrick.jpg | office = 42nd [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas]] | governor = [[Greg Abbott]] | term_start = January 20, 2015 | term_end = | predecessor = [[David Dewhurst]] | successor = | state_senate1 = Texas | district1 = [[Texas Senate, District 7|7th]] | term_start1 = January 9, 2007 | term_end1 = January 13, 2015 | predecessor1 = [[Jon Lindsay]] | successor1 = [[Paul Bettencourt]] | birth_name = Dannie Scott Goeb | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|4|4}} | birth_place = [[Baltimore]], Maryland, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | spouse = ''First wife'' (Divorced)
Jan Rankin (1975–present) | children = 2, including [[Ryan Patrick|Ryan]] | education = [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) | website = {{url|https://www.ltgov.state.tx.us/}} }} '''Dan Goeb Patrick''' (born '''Dannie Scott Goeb''';{{cite web|url=http://www.danpatrick.org/truth/|title=The Truth – Name Change » Dan Patrick for Lieutenant Governor|work=Dan Patrick for Lieutenant Governor|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141104162818/http://www.danpatrick.org/truth/ |archive-date=4 November 2014 |accessdate=15 November 2018}} April 4, 1950){{cite web |url = http://www.texastribune.org/directory/dan-patrick/ |title = State Sen. Dan Patrick |work = The Texas Tribune |series = Elected Officials Directory |accessdate = November 3, 2012}}{{cite web |url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/politics/here-comes-trouble/ |title=Here Comes Trouble |last=Swartz |first=Mimi |magazine=Texas Monthly |date=January 2007 |accessdate=December 28, 2017}} is an [[Americans|American]] [[radio host|radio talk show host]] and [[politician]]. He is the 42nd and current [[Lieutenant Governor of Texas|lieutenant governor of Texas]], serving since January 2015. Originally from [[Baltimore]], Maryland, Patrick began his career as a radio and television broadcaster. After forming a chain of sports bars and subsequently going bankrupt, he became a radio host again, this time becoming a conservative commentator. From 2007 to 2015, Patrick was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] member of the [[Texas Senate]] for the [[Texas Senate, District 7|7th District]], which included a small portion of the city of Houston and several [[Greater Houston|Houston-area]] [[suburb]]s located mostly in northwest [[Harris County, Texas|Harris County]]. Patrick defeated three-term incumbent [[David Dewhurst]] in the [[runoff election|primary runoff]] for lieutenant governor on May 27, 2014.[http://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/state-politics/20140527-dan-patrick-wins-gop-nomination-for-texas-lieutenant-governor.ece Dan Patrick wins GOP nomination for Texas lieutenant governor] -Terrence Stutz and Robert Garrett, [[Dallas Morning News]] He then won the position in the [[Texas lieutenant gubernatorial election, 2014|fall general election]]. He was re-elected in 2018, defeating Democratic nominee Mike Collier. ==Early life== Patrick was born in [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]], on April 4, 1950. He was reared in a [[Blue-collar worker|blue-collar]] neighborhood in East Baltimore. He is the only child of the former Vilma Jean Marshall (1926–2016) and Charles Anthony Goeb (1926–2002), who worked at the ''[[Baltimore Sun]]'' for thirty-one years as a newspaper vendor,''[[San Antonio Express News]]'', April 17, 2014 before he retired in 1984. In later life, he legally changed his surname from Goeb to Patrick.{{cite news |title=GOEB 12/20/2002 |date=December 20, 2002 |url=http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/obits_3610530/goeb.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130119062432/http://www.chron.com/CDA/archives/archive.mpl/obits_3610530/goeb.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 19, 2013 |newspaper=Houston Chronicle |accessdate=November 3, 2012}} Patrick graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in [[English studies|English]] from the [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]]; he is the first member of his family to graduate from college.{{cite web |url=http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/members/dist7/dist7.htm |title=Senator Dan Patrick: District 7 |publisher=Texas Senate |work=Members of the Texas State Senate |accessdate=November 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025132120/http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/Members/dist7/Dist7.htm |archivedate=October 25, 2012 |df= }} ==Pre-political career== ===Radio and television=== Patrick started his first radio job in 1968 at the age of 18. After college, in 1977, he became a television broadcaster at [[WNEP-TV]] in [[Scranton, Pennsylvania|Scranton]], [[Pennsylvania]]. Patrick later held a similar position at [[WTTG]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], before he became the lead sportscaster with [[KHOU-TV]] in Houston.{{cite web | last1=Sweeney | first1=Paul | title=Party Crasher | url=https://www.texasobserver.org/2143-party-crasher-can-houstons-king-of-right-wing-talk-radio-bust-into-the-texas-senate/ | date=February 24, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Texas Observer]]'' | accessdate=December 19, 2016}} As a broadcaster, Patrick was able to get attention through various stunts, such as painting himself blue in support for the [[Houston Oilers]] and wearing a large [[cowboy hat]]. He became the second most popular TV personality in Houston by 1983, as well as one of the most well-known, though surveys also found that he was one of the most disliked. Patrick also had excellent public speaking skills, which caused him to be nicknamed "the Silver-tongued Devil." Patrick left his job at KHOU in the mid-1980s after failing to reach an agreement with the station's new ownership for a long-term contract. According to Patrick, as his surname from birth, ''Goeb'', was not pleasant-sounding or spelled as it sounded, he did not use it from his first day as a radio host. Instead, he used the [[pseudonym]] ''Dan Scott''. When Patrick became a television broadcaster in 1977, he changed his air name at the request of the person who hired him in order to avoid confusing Patrick with another anchor at a competitor station with the last name of Scott. Patrick chose ''Dan Patrick'', with "Patrick" being his [[middle name]] of his wife's brother. Patrick continued to use this name, and by the time he legally changed his name around 2004, he and his family were known as ''the Patricks''. ===Sports bar chain and bankruptcy=== In November 1983, Patrick and several investors opened one of the first sports bars in the U.S., which they named Dan and Nick’s Sportsmarket. The bar did well for a time, due to "the strength of Patrick’s personality" and an oil boom in Houston at the time, and they eventually took ownership of five sports bars in the city. Patrick's mother was the company bookkeeper. Questions later arose during the 2014 lieutenant governor's race about the [[immigration]] status of one of Patrick's employees, Miguel "Mike" Andrade. Patrick and Andrade offered different recollections about Andrade's employment. The matter was raised by one of Patrick's opponents, Jerry Patterson, who questioned Patrick's declared commitment to halt illegal immigration."Patrick: No knowledge of worker's status", ''[[Laredo Morning Times]]'', February 20, 2014, p. 8A When the oil boom ended, Houston's economy fell, something which fatally hurt Patrick's sports bar chain. In 1986, after the sports bars failed, Patrick filed for [[personal bankruptcy]]. In October 1992, the case was closed, discharging several hundred thousand dollars in remaining debts.{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/headlines/20130919-dan-patrick-walked-away-from-large-business-debts.ece|title=Lieutenant governor candidate Dan Patrick knows struggles of going broke|publisher=Dallas News |date=September 19, 2013|accessdate=May 28, 2014}} Patrick, who stated it took him 10 years for him and his family "to regain financial equilibrium," has frequently and openly discussed the ordeal and stated how it shaped him as an individual and [[Conservatism in the United States|conservative]]. ===Conservative talk radio host=== Soon after his bankruptcy, Patrick "reinvented himself." He became a [[conservative talk radio]] host in the 1990s. He began by buying a four-hour timeslot at [[AM 700]] [[KSEV]] (then called KTBT) in the summer of 1987. He originally was a [[sports radio]] host, operating out of his remaining sports bar. However, he was able to take over the radio station in 1988, and he switched to politics shortly afterward.{{cite web | last1=Malewitz | first1=Jim | last2=Walters | first2=Edgar | title=Radio Made Dan Patrick Powerful in Texas. And it's Helping Him Stay that Way. | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2017/07/27/radio-made-texas-lt-gov-dan-patrick-powerful-and-its-helping-him-stay-/ | date=July 27, 2017 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=December 28, 2017}} He hosted a [[American conservatism|conservative]] radio talk show. The program, ''Dan Patrick & Friends'', was broadcast in the Houston [[media market|radio market]] on KSEV and in [[Dallas]] on [[AM 1160]] [[KBDT|KVCE]].{{cite web |url=http://www.kvceradio.com/host-bios/dan-patrick/ |title=Dan Patrick host bio |publisher=1160 KVCE AM Radio Dallas |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160111111700/http://www.kvceradio.com/host-bios/dan-patrick/ |archive-date= January 11, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://ksevradio.com/hosts/dan-patrick |title=Dan Patrick host information page |publisher=KSEV Radio – 700 AM |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924111750/http://ksevradio.com/hosts/dan-patrick |archive-date= September 24, 2014}} Patrick grew successful and influential through his talk radio career. He earned high name recognition. As a talk radio host, Patrick advocated for [[fiscal conservatism]], [[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christian]] values [[Christian right|on social issues]], and he became a vocal opponent of [[illegal immigration]]. He was also known as a [[populist]]. Patrick's talk radio career was instrumental to his political rise, including his election and influence in the State Senate and his eventual election as lieutenant governor. One notable decision Patrick made as the owner of a talk radio station was to sign [[Rush Limbaugh]], who was not well known at the time, to be heard on KSEV in 1989, via [[radio syndication]]. Limbaugh's success as a national talk show host helped raise the popularity of Patrick's radio station. By February 2006, Patrick already owned one radio station. In 2006, Patrick signed a deal to purchase radio station KMGS AM 1160 in [[Highland Park, Texas|Highland Park]], Texas (now [[KBDT]]).{{cite news |first=Kristen |last=Mack |title=Alvarado looks in Dallas for Latino legal support |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/mack/3994763.html |publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=June 23, 2006 |accessdate=November 3, 2012}}{{better source|reason=Source is not clear. Did Patrick create the radio station or did he purchase it? The story talks about another politician joining Patrick in his venture.|date=December 2016}} By 2013, Patrick was the majority owner of two radio stations, in Houston and Dallas radio markets. Patrick continued broadcasting after his election as a State Senator, and he continued to own KSEV after his election as lieutenant governor. ===Other=== Patrick considered running for the [[United States House of Representatives]] in 2004. According to Patrick, while he was still considering a congressional run he changed his legal name to his air name of ''Dan Patrick'' as candidates could only list their legal name on the ballot rather than a [[pseudonym]]. In November 2008, Patrick began work to produce ''The Heart of Texas'', a movie based on a real-life story of two families in [[Simonton, Texas|Simonton]], a small Houston-area city. The movie was released the next year on DVD.{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/life/hoffman/article/Hoffman-State-Sen-Dan-Patrick-Hollywood-is-1762900.php |title=State Sen. Dan Patrick, Hollywood is calling |publisher=Houston Chronicle |date=November 19, 2008 |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |last=Hoffman |first=Ken}}{{cite web |url=http://bignews.biz/?id=793436&keys=Heart-Texas-documentary-dvd |title=Press release announcing DVD's release |date=January 31, 2009 |publisher=BigNews.biz |accessdate=November 4, 2012}} Patrick proposed a [[boycott]] of [[Bill Maher]]'s television show ''[[Politically Incorrect]]'' over controversial statements made by the comedian following the [[9/11]] terrorist attacks.[http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Blogs/News?subject=oid%3A466283 "Beyond City Limits: Dan Patrick, Fairness Isn't Enough for Dan"], ''Austin Chronicle'', April 12, 2007. Patrick is also frequently at odds with the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' and announced a [[boycott]] of that newspaper in April 2004.Abrahams, Tom. "Radio talk show host launches boycott against local newspaper", ''ABC-TV 13 Houston'', April 9, 2004. He owned a blog called ''Chronically Biased '', which criticized the newspaper. ==Texas Senate== ===First term=== Patrick was first elected to [[Texas State Senate]]'s [[Texas Senate, District 7|seventh district]] in 2006, winning the [[primary election]] with 68.8% of the vote and the general election with 69.2% of the vote. His term began on January 9, 2007 with the convening of the [[Eightieth Texas Legislature]]. During his first month as a legislator, Patrick introduced Senate Bill 186.{{cite web|url=http://www.capitol.state.tx.us/tlodocs/80R/billtext/html/SB00186I.htm |title=80(R) SB 186 – Introduced version – Bill Text |publisher=Capitol.state.tx.us |date=September 1, 2007 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}} If passed, it would have made abortion in Texas illegal should the [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] overturn ''[[Roe v. Wade]]''. The bill was co-sponsored by fellow Texas state senators [[Craig Estes]] and [[Glenn Hegar]].{{cite web |url=http://www.capitol.state.tx.us/BillLookup/History.aspx?LegSess=80R&Bill=SB186 |title=80(R) History for SB 186 |publisher=Texas Legislature Online |accessdate=November 4, 2012}} Patrick obtained passage of three Senate bills during his first session, the fewest number among the five freshmen senators.{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.state.tx.us/Reports/Report.aspx?ID=author&LegSess=80R&code=A1430|title=Texas Legislature Online – Report|publisher=Legis.state.tx.us|accessdate=January 13, 2015}} The other four freshmen Senators—Glenn Hegar (32 Senate bills passed), [[Kirk Watson]] (15 Senate bills passed), [[Robert Nichols (Texas politician)|Robert Nichols]] (14 Senate bills passed), and [[Carlos Uresti]] (12 bills passed) – had previous government experience in other capacities.{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/Members.htm|title=The Texas State Senate: Current Members of the Texas Senate|publisher=www.Senate.state.tx.us|accessdate=January 13, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971210182106/http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/members.htm|archivedate=December 10, 1997|df=}} ===Second term=== [[File:State Sen. Dan Patrick (8428437478).jpg|thumb|Patrick at a 2013 press conference on education]] In the [[Texas elections, 2010|2010 general election]], Patrick was reelected with 86.4% of the vote. He also endorsed [[Rick Perry]] for re-election in the [[Texas gubernatorial election, 2010|2010 election]].[http://www.star-telegram.com/news/columnists/bud_kennedy/story/1506661.html]{{dead link|date=May 2014}} Soon after winning re-election, Patrick announced, and subsequently created, a [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] Caucus in the [[Texas state legislature]], which at its creation had 48 legislative members.Grissom, Brandi (December 16, 2010) – [http://www.texastribune.org/2010/12/16/sen-dan-patrick-announces-tea-party-caucus/ "Sen. Dan Patrick Announces Tea Party Caucus"]. ''The texas Tribune''. Retrieved February 5, 2015. W. Gardner Selby, editor of the ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'''s "PolitiFact Texas", listed Patrick as third among the top 10 Republican political influencers in Texas.(Texas Influencers, August 2010) Patrick is also listed in ''[[Texas Monthly]]'' as one of the state's most powerful players.(Power Company, February 2011) In May 2012, acrimony between Patrick and fellow Republican state senator [[John Carona]] was widely reported throughout Texas.{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/news/news/state-regional-govt-politics/emails-provide-rare-glimpse-inside-senate-politi-1/nRnbB/|title=Emails provide rare glimpse inside Senate politics|last=Ward |first=Mike |work=Austin American-Statesman|date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=November 4, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mysanantonio.com/news/politics/texas_legislature/article/Senators-nasty-emails-refer-to-personal-lives-3540822.php|title=Senators' nasty emails refer to personal lives|last=Fikac|first=Peggy|work=[[San Antonio Express News]]|date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=May 8, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Senators-Patrick-Carona-make-it-personal-in-3541096.php|work=Houston Chronicle|last=Fikac|first=Peggy|title=Senators Patrick, Carona make it personal in email spat|date=May 7, 2012|accessdate=May 8, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://frontburner.dmagazine.com/2012/05/07/gossip-wars-sens-john-carona-and-dan-patrick/|last=Heid|first=Jason|date=May 7, 2012|accessdate= May 8, 2012|work= D Magazine|title=Gossip Wars: Sens. John Carona and Dan Patrick}} In an email exchange, Patrick accused Carona of spreading false rumors about Patrick's marriage. Carona denied that, and additionally denied having commented on Patrick's sexuality. Carona further said to Patrick: "I've never been shy about sharing my dislike and distrust of you. Put bluntly, I believe you are a snake oil salesman, a narcissist that would say anything to draw attention to himself." News reports suggest that the feud was motivated by positioning to succeed David Dewhurst as lieutenant governor should Dewhurst have won a seat as U.S. senator, in 2012. ===Committee assignments=== * Committee on Education (Chair) * Committee on Criminal Justice * Committee on Finance * Committee on Health & Human Services * Committee on Intergovernmental Relations * Committee on Finance ** Subcommittee on Fiscal Matters ** Subcommittee on Public Education Funding ** Subcommittee on Higher Education Funding ==Lieutenant governor of Texas== ===2014 campaign=== {{See also|Texas elections, 2014#Lieutenant Governor}} On June 26, 2013, Patrick announced he would challenge incumbent David Dewhurst in the Republican primary for lieutenant governor in 2014.{{cite web|last=Hamilton |first=Reeve |url=http://www.texastribune.org/2013/06/27/coming-out-swinging-dan-patrick-announces-lt-gov/ |title=Coming Out Swinging, Dan Patrick Announces for Lt. Gov. |publisher=The Texas Tribune |date=July 7, 2013 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}} This challenge came despite Patrick's enthusiastic endorsement of Dewhurst in his failed 2012 bid for the U.S. Senate.{{cite web|url=http://www.redstate.com/irish067/2012/07/27/joann-fleming-slams-patrick-over-dewhurst-endorsement/ |title=JoAnn Fleming Slams Patrick Over Dewhurst Endorsement |publisher=RedState |accessdate=May 1, 2014}}{{cite web|last=Messamore |first=Andrew |url=http://blog.chron.com/texaspolitics/2012/07/dan-patrick-endorses-dewhurst/ |title=Dan Patrick endorses Dewhurst – Texas Politics |publisher=Blog.chron.com |date=July 26, 2012 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}} Patrick stated that while he had been planning on retiring from politics after his Senate term ended, he decided to run for lieutenant governor after Dewhurst failed to end fellow State Senator [[Wendy Davis (politician)|Wendy Davis]]'s filibuster of [[Texas Senate Bill 5]] and after Senator [[Jane Nelson]] refused to run herself. In his race for lieutenant governor, Patrick was endorsed in July 2013 by [[Mike Huckabee]], the former [[governor of Arkansas]] who ran unsuccessfully for the [[U.S. presidential election, 2008|2008 Republican presidential nomination]]. In 2012, Huckabee had also endorsed David Dewhurst for the U.S. Senate nomination for the seat vacated by [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]].{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com/texaspolitics/2013/07/patrick-touts-huckabee-endorsement/|title=Patrick touts Huckabee endorsement, July 23, 2013|publisher=blog.chron.com|accessdate=July 24, 2013}} Victory went, however, to the Republican [[Ted Cruz]]. At a candidate forum in [[College Station, Texas|College Station]] in January 2014, Patrick said that he and two other challengers to Dewhurst, [[Jerry E. Patterson]] and [[Todd Staples]], could have sought re-election in their current positions as [[Texas General Land Office|Land Commissioner]] and [[Texas Commissioner of Agriculture]], respectively, but were instead "putting our positions on the line because we need new leadership. ... An energetic, passionate conservative to lead the Senate."{{cite web|url=http://www.theeagle.com/news/local/article_eb860364-bdde-543d-9554-7f4622c89351.html|title=Beth Brown, "GOP lieutenant governor candidates reach out to Bryan-College Station voters," January 9, 2013|publisher=''[[Bryan-College Station Eagle]]''|accessdate=January 9, 2014}} At the candidate forum, Patrick described education as a key issue in his campaign because of the 25 percent statewide high school drop-out rate, rising to 40 to 50 percent in the inner cities. He stated that "we do not have a future in the state of Texas if we have half of the next adult population – majority being Hispanic – don't have a high school degree." Patrick said that as lieutenant governor, he would work to secure the border with [[Mexico]] and to abolish [[sanctuary cities]] and in-state tuition for illegal immigrants. He also called for lowering [[property tax]]es. Patrick led the four-candidate field in the primary with 550,769 votes (41.5%). Dewhurst followed with 376,196 (28.3%); Staples, with 235,981 (17.8%), and Patterson, 165,787 (12.5%).{{cite web|url=https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar04_169_state.htm?x=0&y=218&id=176 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140305180619/https://team1.sos.state.tx.us/enr/results/mar04_169_state.htm?x=0&y=218&id=176 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 5, 2014 |title=Republican primary election returns, March 4, 2014 |publisher=enr.sos.state.tx.us |accessdate=March 5, 2014 |df= }} Election watchers did not expect Patrick to get first place.{{cite web | last1=Hooks | first1=Christopher | title=The Ascendancy of Dan Patrick | url=https://www.texasobserver.org/ascendancy-dan-patrick/ | date=March 5, 2014 | publisher=[[The Texas Observer]] | accessdate=September 20, 2018}} In the runoff election on May 27, Patrick won with 487,829 votes (65.1%), defeating Dewhurst, who had 262,086 votes (34.9%).{{cite news | last1=Fernandez | first1=Manny | title=Lieutenant Governor Loses Texas Runoff as Tea Party Holds Sway | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/28/us/politics/tea-party-favorite-beats-lieutenant-governor-in-texas.html | date=May 27, 2014 | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=January 24, 2015}}{{cite web | last1=Stutz | first1=Terrence | last2=Garrett | first2=Robert T. | title=Dan Patrick Wins GOP Nomination for Texas Lieutenant Governor | url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-politics/2014/05/27/dan-patrick-wins-gop-nomination-for-texas-lieutenant-governor | date=May 27, 2014 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=January 10, 2018}} Patrick's victory was one of several notable primary victories by [[Tea Party movement]]-aligned Republicans in the election runoff.{{cite web | last1=Grissom | first1=Brandi | title=Tea Party Conservatives Win Top GOP Runoffs | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2014/05/28/tea-party-conservatives-win-top-gop-runoff-contest/ | date=May 28, 2014 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=January 10, 2018}} According to Ross Ramsey of ''[[The Texas Tribune]]'', Patrick did not shift to the political middle as the general election approached, contrary to what political candidates typically do.{{cite web | last1=Ramsey | first1=Ross | title=Analysis: Who’s the Establishment, Anyway? | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/01/10/analysis-whos-establishment-anyway/ | date=January 10, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=January 10, 2017}} On November 4, 2014, Patrick won the general election against his state Senate colleague, [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] [[Leticia Van de Putte]] of [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], to become the lieutenant governor-elect of Texas. He was swept into office in a Republican landslide that saw the party retain all statewide elected offices for the fifth consecutive election. ===2018 campaign=== {{See also|Texas elections, 2018#Lieutenant Governor}} On January 9, 2017, the day before the 85th Texas Legislature began its session, Patrick announced he would run for re-election in 2018.{{cite web | last1=Whitely | first1=Jason | title=Lt. Gov. Patrick Announces Re-Election Campaign | url=http://www.wfaa.com/news/politics/lt-gov-patrick-announces-re-election-campaign/384424961 | date=January 9, 2017 | publisher=[[WFAA]] | accessdate=January 10, 2017}} He stated his early announcement was in order to dispel rumors that he would challenge Governor [[Greg Abbott]] or U.S. Senator [[Ted Cruz]]. Patrick easily won the Republican primary on March 6, 2018, defeating [[Rockwall, Texas|Rockwall]] City Council Member Scott Milder.{{cite web | last1=McGaughy | first1=Lauren | title=Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Shreds GOP Challenger, Will Face Mike Collier in General Election | url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2018-elections/2018/03/06/lt-gov-dan-patrick-shreds-republican-challenger-will-face-mike-collier-november | date=March 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=March 7, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Walsh | first1=Sean Collins | title=Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Defeats GOP Challenger Scott Milder | url=https://www.statesman.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/gov-dan-patrick-defeats-gop-challenger-scott-milder/G0fVSSCSLFS9M2aYvb6lbN/new.html | date= | publisher= | accessdate=}} In addition to his own campaign, Patrick was active in endorsing and assisting Republican primary candidates in the Texas Senate, including some challengers to GOP incumbents.{{cite web | last1=Jeffers | first1=Gromer, Jr. | title=Already Playing with a Strong Hand, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Gambles by Endorsing in GOP Primaries | url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2018-elections/2018/02/21/already-playing-strong-hand-lt-gov-dan-patrick-gambles-endorsing-gop-primaries | date=February 21, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=September 20, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Prazan | first1=Phil | title=Dan Patrick Picks Sides in GOP Primary Races for the Texas Senate | url=https://www.kxan.com/news/local/austin/dan-patrick-picks-sides-in-gop-primary-races-for-the-texas-senate_20180312075314850/1031474849 | date= | publisher=[[KXAN-TV]] | accessdate=September 20, 2018}} Patrick's favored candidates won nearly all the races where Patrick made intraparty endorsements.{{cite web | last1=Formby | first1=Brandon | last2=Greene | first2=Sydney | title=GOP State Sen. Craig Estes Ousted; Sen. Bob Hall Defeats Burkett | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/03/06/craig-estes-angela-paxton-bob-hall-texas-senate-primary-2018/ | date=March 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=September 20, 2018}} Later in the year, Patrick donated nearly $175,000 to Texas Senate candidate [[Pete Flores]] in a special election; Flores won the election in an upset, increasing Patrick's chances of keeping a three-fifths GOP majority in the Senate after the 2018 elections.{{cite web | last1=McGuinness | first1=Dylan | title=Flores Defeats Gallego in Senate District 19 | url=https://www.mysanantonio.com/news/local/article/Polls-close-at-7-p-m-in-Senate-District-19-13239398.php | date=September 19, 2018 | publisher=''[[San Antonio Express-News]]'' | accessdate=September 20, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Svitek | first1=Patrick | title=Republican Pete Flores Upsets Democrat Pete Gallego in Race for Uresti Seat | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/09/18/republican-pete-flores-track-upset-race-democratic-friendly-uresti-sea/ | date=September 18, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=September 20, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Ratcliffe | first1=R.G. | title=The Texas Democratic Party Has Lost the Ability to Sell Its Brand | url=https://www.texasmonthly.com/politics/texas-democratic-party-lost-ability-sell-brand/ | date=September 19, 2018 | publisher=''[[Texas Monthly]]'' | accessdate=September 20, 2018}} Patrick succeeded in maintaining a three-fifths majority in the Senate, though Republican Senator [[Kel Seliger]] was considered a possible swing-vote.{{cite web | last1=McGaughy | first1=Lauren | title=Democrats Flip Two Texas Senate Seats, Creating Key GOP Swing Vote in the Process | url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2018-elections/2018/11/07/democrats-flip-two-texas-senate-seats-create-key-gop-swing-vote-process | date=November 7, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=November 8, 2018}} In the November 6 general election, Patrick won re-election to a second term,{{cite web | last1=Marfin | first1=Catherine | title=Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick defeats Democrat Mike Collier | url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/politics/texas/article/With-much-of-early-vote-counted-Lt-Gov-Dan-13368728.php | date=November 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' | accessdate=November 7, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Cunningham | first1=Chelsea | title=Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick defeats Mike Collier for second term | url=https://www.khou.com/article/news/politics/elections/texas-lt-gov-dan-patrick-defeats-mike-collier-for-second-term/285-612126278 | date=November 7, 2018 | publisher=[[KHOU]] | accessdate=November 7, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Zdun | first1=Matt | last2=Collier | first2=Kiah | title=Gov. Greg Abbott clinches second term as GOP wins closest statewide races in 20 years | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2018/11/06/greg-abbott-lupe-valdez-dan-patrick-justin-nelson-texas-midterm-2018/ | date=November 6, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=November 7, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Morris | first1=Allie | last2=Zelinski | first2=Andrea | title=Gov. Abbott wins re-election as other statewide Republicans claim victory | url=https://www.chron.com/news/politics/texas/article/Gov-Abbott-wins-re-election-as-other-statewide-13369601.php | date=November 6, 2018 | publisher=''Chron.com'' | accessdate=November 7, 2018}} defeating Democratic nominee Mike Collier. He won about 51% of the vote against Collier's 47%.{{cite web|url=https://enrpages.sos.state.tx.us/public/nov06_331_state.htm?x=0&y=8370&id=374|title=Election Returns|date=November 6, 2018|publisher=[[Texas Secretary of State]]|accessdate=November 7, 2018}} ===Tenure=== [[File:Donald Trump Dallas 2017.jpg|thumb|200px|Patrick, third from left, attending an October 2017 meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump, Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]], and [[Federal Emergency Management Agency|FEMA officials]], on [[Hurricane Harvey]] relief and recovery efforts.]] Patrick was sworn in on January 20, 2015.Lindell, Chuck (January 20, 2015). [http://www.statesman.com/news/news/dan-patrick-snaps-selfies-vows-next-level-conserva/njr2K/ "Dan Patrick Snaps Selfies, Vows ‘Next Level’ Conservatism"]. ''Austin American -Statesman''. Retrieved January 23, 2015.Fernandez, Manny (January 20, 2015). [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/21/us/politics/new-texas-governor-greg-abbott-expected-to-continue-on-perrys-path.html?_r=0 "Texas’ New Governor Echoes the Plans of Perry"]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved January 24, 2015. Soon after assuming office, the [[Texas Senate]] voted to drop the threshold needed to consider a bill from two-thirds to three-fifths, something that Patrick had long supported.Smith, Morgan (January 21, 2015). [http://www.texastribune.org/2015/01/21/change-procedure-senate-democrats-lose-clout/ "With Change in Procedure, Senate Democrats Lose Clout"]. ''The Texas Tribune''. Retrieved January 23, 2015.Koppel, Nathan (January 21, 2015). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/texas-lt-gov-dan-patrick-moves-quickly-to-advance-conservative-agenda-1421883867 "Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Moves Quickly to Advance Conservative Agenda"]. ''The Wall Street Journal''. Retrieved January 23, 2015. Under Patrick, the Senate enforced proceedural rules that had long been ignored. Major legislation that Patrick helped pass during his tenure as lieutenant governor include legalization of [[Campus carry in the United States|campus carry]]{{cite web | last1=Jukam | first1=Kelsey | title=The Winners and Losers of the Battle for Campus Carry | url=https://www.texasobserver.org/the-winners-and-losers-of-the-battle-for-campus-carry/ | date=June 3, 2015 | publisher=''The Texas Observer'' | accessdate=September 29, 2016}} and [[Open carry in the United States|open carry]],{{cite web | title=Gov. Abbott signs open carry, campus carry into law | url=http://www.kvue.com/news/state/gov-abbott-signs-open-carry-campus-carry-into-law/152502166 | date=June 13, 2015 | publisher=''KVUE | accessdate=September 29, 2016}} a bill allowing pastors to refuse marrying couples if it violates their beliefs,{{cite web | last1=Crampton | first1=Liz | title=Abbott Signs "Pastor Protection Act" Into Law | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2015/06/11/gov-abbott-signs-pastor-protection-act/ | date=June 11, 2015 | publisher=''The Texas Tribune'' | accessdate=September 29, 2016}} and expanded border security and enforcement measures.{{cite web | title=Lieutenant Governor Dan Patrick and the Texas Senate Achieved Your Priorities | url=https://www.ltgov.state.tx.us/priorities/lieutenant-governor-dan-patrick-and-the-texas-senate-achieved-your-priorities/ | date=June 10, 2015 | publisher=''Office of the Lieutenant Governor'' | accessdate=September 29, 2016}}{{cite web | title=Abbott Signs Budget Into Law | url=http://www.twcnews.com/tx/austin/news/2015/06/21/abbott-signs-budget-into-law.html | date=June 21, 2015 | publisher=''TWC News'' | accessdate=September 29, 2016}} On May 13, 2016, Patrick criticized the [[Obama administration]], after it released a directive stating that all public schools must allow transgender students to use the bathroom and locker facilities that correspond with their identified gender, stating that, on the prospect of the federal government withholding funding for Texas schools for not following the directive, "he can keep his 30 pieces of silver [and that w]e will not yield to blackmail from the president of the United States."{{cite web | last1=Gass | first1=Nick | title=Texas Lt. Gov. Accuses Obama of 'Blackmail' on Transgender Bathrooms | url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/05/transgender-bathrooms-obama-texas-lieutenant-governor-223159 | date=May 13, 2016 | publisher=''[[Politico]]'' | accessdate=May 14, 2016}}{{cite web | last1=Healy | first1=Jack | last2=Pérez-Peñamay | first2=Richard | title=Solace and Fury as Schools React to Transgender Policy | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/14/us/transgender-bathrooms.html?_r=0 | date=May 13, 2016 | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=May 14, 2016}}{{cite news|title=Texas to Instruct Schools Not to Obey Obama's Transgender Bathroom Decree|url=http://insider.foxnews.com/2016/05/13/tx-lt-gov-dan-patrick-transgender-bathrooms-would-be-end-public-education|accessdate=May 14, 2016|publisher=Fox News Insider}} Patrick supported and strongly advocated for a [[bathroom bill]] proposed on January 5, 2017 by Senator [[Lois Kolkhorst]] of [[Brenham, Texas|Brenham]]. Patrick made legislation prohibiting state or local governments from issuing subpoenas on pastors' sermons a priority in the 2017 session. Governor Abbott signed the bill into law on May 21, 2017.{{cite web | last1=Svitek | first1=Patrick | title=Abbott Signs Bill Protecting Sermons from Subpoenas | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2017/05/21/abbott-signs-bill-protecting-sermons-subpoenas/ | date=May 21, 2017 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=May 22, 2017}} ==Political positions== ===Abortion=== Patrick opposes [[abortion]] and supported Texas' "Mandatory Ultrasound Bill", a bill signed into law in May 2011 by Governor Perry, which requires women seeking abortion to have a [[Medical ultrasonography|sonogram]] of the [[fetus]] taken at least twenty-four hours before the abortion is performed.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Patrick opposes abortion in cases of incest and rape. In January 2014, when he was asked about exceptions to outlawing abortion, Patrick said, "The only exception would be if the life of the mother was truly in danger…but that is rare."{{cite web|url=http://www.mystatesman.com/news/news/local/herman-abortion-exceptionalism-in-the-gop-lite-guv/ndC75/#e5ff2779.3657224.735464|title=Herman: Abortion exceptionalism in the GOP lite guv primary|publisher=Mystatesman.com|accessdate=January 13, 2015}} ===Education=== Patrick supports increasing the number of [[charter schools]] in the state. In February 2011, Patrick, who at the time was vice chairman of the Texas senate's [[Texas Senate#Committee Structure|Committee on Education]], spoke in favor of cutting an unspecified number of non-teaching positions from the state's public school districts, citing positions such as "math department supervisors" or "curriculum experts".{{cite news |url=http://www.texastribune.org/texas-education/public-education/do-texas-schools-spend-too-much-on-administration/ |title=Do Texas Schools Spend Too Much on Administration? |publisher=The Texas Tribune |date=February 25, 2011 |first=Morgan |last=Smith |accessdate=November 4, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/commit/c530/c530_81.htm |title=Committee Information for 81st Session's Senate Committee on Education |publisher=Texas State Senate |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026014521/http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/commit/c530/c530_81.htm |archivedate=October 26, 2012 |df= }} At the time, Patrick cited a statistic later determined to be misleading by PolitiFact.com that Texas's 1,200+ public school districts, considered as a group, are the fifth-largest employer in the world.{{cite web |url=http://www.politifact.com/texas/statements/2011/mar/11/dan-patrick/dan-patrick-says-texas-school-districts-all-told-a/ |title=Mostly False: Dan Patrick Says Texas school districts are the fifth largest employers in the world. |publisher=PolitiFact.com |accessdate=November 4, 2012}} Patrick is on record as determined to establish [[creationism]] within the public school curriculum in Texas, despite court rulings that such a policy would violate the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]].{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/bad_astronomy/2014/01/29/creationism_and_texas_once_more_into_the_breach_of_education.html?wpisrc=burger_bar|title=Creationism and Texas: Once more into the breach of education.|work=Slate Magazine|accessdate=January 13, 2015}} ===Fiscal conservatism=== Patrick identifies the experience of his personal bankruptcy as having shaped his conservatism in fiscal policy. Patrick joined with restaurateur Edd Hendee and [[Paul Bettencourt]], the former Harris County tax assessor-collector and Patrick's successor in the state Senate, both on-air hosts on Patrick's station, to form ''Citizens Lowering Our Unfair Taxes'' (CLOUT), a political organization that was originally formed to push for lower property taxes in Texas.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}} ===Illegal immigration=== Patrick opposes [[Illegal immigration to the United States|illegal immigration]]. As a talk radio host, he reserved some of his "most hard-edged oratory for illegal immigrants." Patrick expressed support for [[Arizona SB 1070|Arizona’s SB 1070 immigration enforcement law]], and supports passing a similar law in Texas that would allow local law enforcement to ask lawfully-stopped individuals about their immigration status and would make it a state misdemeanor to be present in Texas as an illegal immigrant.{{cite web|url=http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/members/dist7/pr10/p110810a.htm |title=Press Release from the Office of State Senator Dan Patrick: Senator Dan Patrick Files Conservative Agenda |publisher=Texas State Senate |date=November 8, 2010 |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130112152211/http://www.senate.state.tx.us/75r/senate/members/dist7/pr10/p110810a.htm |archivedate=January 12, 2013 |df= }} As Lieutenant Governor, Patrick moved to keep [[National Guard of the United States|National Guard]] troops sent to the Texas-Mexico border during the illegal immigration surge of 2014 indefinitely, rather than until March 2015, as originally planned.The Associated Press (February 10, 2015) – [http://dfw.cbslocal.com/2015/02/10/lt-gov-patrick-national-guard-not-leaving-texas-border/ "Lt. Gov. Patrick: National Guard Not Leaving Texas Border"]. ''CBS-DFW''. Retrieved February 10, 2015. Patrick's 2015 budget in the [[Texas Senate]] called for spending $815 million on border security, which he said was more than the previous seven years combined. Governor [[Greg Abbott]] signed the measure—for about $800 million—into law.{{cite web | last1=Garrett | first1=Robert T. | title=Abbott Wields Veto Pen to Trim Nearly $300 Million from Texas Budget | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2015/06/20/abbott-wields-veto-pen-to-trim-300-million-from-texas-budget | date=June 20, 2015 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=December 19, 2016}} In a June 2018 interview on [[Fox Business Network]], Patrick estimated that 30 million illegal immigrants lived in the U.S.{{cite web | last1=Giaritelli | first1=Anna | title=As Many as 30 Million People Live in US Illegally, Says Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick | url=https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/as-many-as-30-million-people-live-in-us-illegally-says-texas-lt-gov-dan-patrick | date=June 22, 2018 | publisher=''[[The Washington Examiner]]'' | accessdate=July 2, 2018}} ===Same-sex marriage and LGBT issues=== On February 26, 2014, following a federal court ruling the Texas ban on same-sex marriage unconstitutional, Patrick asserted his position that marriage is a union between one man and one woman. He then further stated his intentions to fight such decisions should he be elected to the Lt. Governor's office.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/DanPatrick/status/438782159138979840 |title=Twitter / DanPatrick: I want to re-emphasize my long |publisher=Twitter.com |date=February 26, 2014 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}}{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/DanPatrick/status/438761650137493504 |title=Twitter / DanPatrick: As Lieutenant Governor I'll |publisher=Twitter.com |date=February 26, 2014 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}} Patrick strongly opposed HERO, an unsuccessful [[Houston]] ordinance intended to establish legal protections for gay and transgender residents along with some other classes, as he claimed that the ordinance would lead to sexual predators being freely able to enter women's restrooms.{{cite news|last1=Driessen|first1=Katherine|title=Patrick takes aim at HERO, mayor|url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/article/Dan-Patrick-takes-aim-at-HERO-mayor-6578348.php|accessdate=May 14, 2016|publisher=''[[The Houston Chronicle]]''}}{{cite web | last1=Ura | first1=Alexa | title=Bathroom Fears Flush Houston Discrimination Ordinance | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2015/11/03/houston-anti-discrimination-ordinance-early-voting/ | date=November 3, 2015 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=May 14, 2016}} Patrick has stated that if necessary, he would support legislation to require people to use the bathroom that corresponds to the gender listed on their birth certificates.{{cite web | last1=Ward | first1=Mike | last2=Hinchliffe | first2=Emma | title=Patrick Says He Would Support a State Transgender Bathroom Law | url=http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/politics/texas/article/Patrick-says-he-would-support-a-state-transgender-7377531.php | date=April 26, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Houston Chronicle]]'' | accessdate=May 14, 2016}} Hours after the [[2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]], Patrick tweeted a picture of the Bible verse, "Do not be deceived: God cannot be mocked. A man reaps what he sows. Galatians 6:7." An adviser released a statement that the tweet had been pre-scheduled, and the tweet was later deleted.{{cite web | last1=Hamilton | first1=Jessica | title=Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick deletes "reap what you sow" tweet after mass shooting at LGBT club | url=http://www.chron.com/news/article/Texas-Lt-Governor-Dan-Patrick-tweets-reap-what-8076147.php | date=June 12, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Houston Chronicle]]'' | accessdate=June 12, 2016}}{{cite web | last1=Blakemore | first1=Allen | title=Statement Regarding Orlando Tragedy and Twitter and Facebook Post | url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/315502915/PR-16-06-12 | date=June 12, 2016 | accessdate=June 12, 2016}} Patrick issued a statement on the incident, again stating that the tweet was pre-planned and that "I didn’t pull down the FB post & tweet because God’s word is wrong. His word is never wrong ... I took it down to stop the hateful comments and the misinformation being spread of God’s message to all of us- straight or gay."{{cite web | last1=Patrick | first1=Dan | title=My Facebook Statement Regarding This Morning’s Bible Verse Post | url=http://danpatrick.org/facebook-statement-regarding-mornings-bible-verse-post/ | publisher=''danpatrick.org'' | accessdate=December 17, 2017}} Patrick encouraged state Senator [[Lois Kolkhorst]] of [[Brenham, Texas|Brenham]] to introduce a [[bathroom bill]] similar to a [[Public Facilities Privacy & Security Act|previous law adopted in 2016]] in [[North Carolina]], and strongly pushed for it at its proposal on January 5, 2017.{{cite web | last1=Svitek | first1=Patrick | title=With Bathroom Bill, Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Plows into "Tough Fight" | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2017/01/07/bathroom-bill-patrick-plows-tough-fight/ | date=January 7, 2017 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=January 10, 2017}} [[Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives|Texas House Speaker]] [[Joe Straus]] of [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], a [[Factions in the Republican Party (United States)#Moderate wing|moderate Republican]], said that the measure is not an important matter for lower chamber.Bobby Cervantes, "Bathroom legislation now ready for debate: Bruising battle looms over transgender bill", ''[[San Antonio Express-News]]'', January 6, 2016, pp. 1, A11 ====Domestic partner benefits==== In November 2012, Patrick asked [[Texas Attorney General|Texas attorney general]] [[Greg Abbott]]'s office to issue an opinion on the constitutionality of government entities providing domestic partner insurance benefits. An [[Texas Proposition 2 (2005)|amendment to the Texas Constitution]] in 2005 limits marriage to heterosexual relationships and prohibits similar, alternative legal arrangements. Patrick did not disclose his own views on [[same-sex marriage]] or [[civil union]]s for same-sex couples. He told the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' that his request was prompted by [[Dallas County, Texas|Dallas County's]] November 2012 decision and an [[Pflugerville Independent School District|Austin-area public school district's]] October 2012 decision to join other Texas cities and counties in extending benefits to their unmarried employees' heterosexual or homosexual partners.{{cite news |url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Patrick-questions-legality-of-domestic-4004790.php |last=Hassan |first=Anita |date=November 2, 2012 |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |title=Sen. Patrick questions legality of domestic partnership benefits |work=Houston Chronicle}} ===Statutory rape laws=== Patrick was interviewed extensively on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s ''[[20/20 (US television series)|20/20]]'' segment "The Age of Consent: When Young Love Is a Sex Crime," defending his position favoring very tough Texas [[statutory rape]] laws. "While it seems unfair, he was 19, she was 15," says Patrick, "That's the price you pay. Even if you end up getting married."{{cite news |first=John |last=Stossel |author2=Gena Binkley |author3=Andrew G. Sullivan |title=The Age of Consent: When Young Love Is a Sex Crime |url=http://abcnews.go.com/print?id=4400537 |work=ABC News |publisher=ABCNews Internet Ventures |date=March 7, 2008 |accessdate=July 19, 2008 }} ===Confederate monuments=== Patrick is a strong supporter of maintaining [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] monuments on public display, despite opposition from civil rights groups who consider the statues as a defense of the institution of [[slavery]]. As one of six members of the board that oversees the [[Texas State Capitol]] grounds, Patrick described the need: "to learn from history all of our history, including events and times that many would like to forget. ... Our goal should be to have a meaningful dialogue for future generations so those moments in our history are not repeated."Allie Morris, "Austin has a monumental problem: Confederate icons have backing at the Capitol," ''San Antonio Express-News,'' August 17, 2017, pp. 1, A6. ===Presidential politics=== {{See also|United States presidential election in Texas, 2016}} Patrick endorsed Texas Senator [[Ted Cruz]] for the [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2016|2016 Republican presidential primaries]] and served as his Texas [[Ted Cruz presidential campaign, 2016|campaign]] chairman.{{cite web | title=Texas' Lt. Gov. Now Backing Ted Cruz's Campaign for President | url=http://www.twcnews.com/tx/austin/politics/2015/10/26/lt--gov--dan-patrick-named-texas-chairman-of-ted-cruz-for-president-campaign.html | date=October 26, 2015 | publisher=''TWC News'' | accessdate=September 29, 2015}} After businessman [[Donald Trump]] became the Republican nominee, Patrick endorsed Trump and eventually became the Texas state chairman for [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|his campaign]].{{cite web | last1=Svitek | first1=Patrick | title=Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Named Trump's Texas Chairman | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2016/09/16/patrick-named-trumps-texas-state-chairman/ | date=September 16, 2016 | publisher=''The Texas Tribune'' | accessdate=September 29, 2016}} Trump won Texas by 9 percentage points, the closest result since [[United States presidential election in Texas, 1996|1996]].{{cite web | last1=Svitek | first1=Patrick | title=Donald Trump's Shocking Upset Emboldens Texas GOP | url=https://www.texastribune.org/2016/11/09/trumps-impact-texas-gop-unlikely-soon-fade/ | date=November 9, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Texas Tribune]]'' | accessdate=December 19, 2016}} In January 2018, Patrick stated that he considered Presidents Trump and [[Ronald Reagan]] as the two greatest presidents in his lifetime,{{cite web | last1=Wallace | first1=Jeremy | title=Dan Patrick: Trump is Greatest President Since Reagan | url=http://www.chron.com/news/politics/texas/article/Trump-one-of-the-two-greatest-presidents-since-12481441.php | date=January 8, 2018 | publisher=''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' | accessdate=January 8, 2018}}{{cite web | last1=Chang | first1=Julie | title=Lt. Gov. Patrick: Trump Joins Reagan Among Best Presidents | url=http://www.statesman.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/gov-patrick-trump-joins-reagan-among-best-presidents/0qURfZmAW2EdYyibcbjuVO/ | date=January 9, 2018 | publisher=''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' | accessdate=January 9, 2018}} and the ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' described Patrick as an "ardent defender" of Trump.{{cite web | last1=Fikac | first1=Peggy | title=Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick is Trump’s Top Texas Cheerleader | url=http://www.expressnews.com/news/news_columnists/peggy_fikac/article/Lt-Gov-Dan-Patrick-is-Trump-s-top-Texas-12496984.php | date=January 14, 2018 | publisher=''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' | accessdate=January 14, 2017}} ==Personal life== Patrick's first marriage ended in divorce. His second wife is Janetlea "Jan" Patricia Rankin, a former [[teacher]]. The couple was married in 1975 and lives in the Houston suburb of [[Cypress, Texas|Cypress]]. They have two children, [[Ryan Patrick|Ryan]] and Shane.{{cite web|url=http://www.patrick.senate.state.tx.us/ |title=The Texas State Senate: District 7 |publisher=Texas State Senate |accessdate=November 4, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121026212419/http://www.patrick.senate.state.tx.us/ |archivedate=October 26, 2012 |df= }} Ryan served as a district judge from [[Harris County, Texas]], and swore in his father in 2015, for his term as lieutenant governor of Texas. In July 2017, Ryan Patrick was chosen to be [[United States Attorney|U.S. Attorney]] for the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas|Southern District of Texas]] by U.S. President [[Donald Trump]], and the [[United States Senate]] subsequently confirmed him. ===Religious views=== While growing up, Patrick and his family were "not very religious."{{cite web | last1=Tilove | first1=Jonathan | title=As Lieutenant Governor, Dan Patrick Remains a 'Christian First' | url=http://www.mystatesman.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/lieutenant-governor-dan-patrick-remains-christian-first/K53MlGMem1cZSfC2rPe4XJ/ | date=April 4, 2015 | publisher=''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' | accessdate=December 28, 2017}} After moving to Houston, he and his wife attended a Catholic church, but he joined a Baptist church soon after learning about it. Though Patrick was a member of the [[Second Baptist Church Houston]] since 1992, he stated he was not truly a Christian until March 1994, when, on a television-and-radio convention in [[Las Vegas]], he repented of his sins, committed his life to God, and was saved.{{cite web | last1=Walsh | first1=Sean Collins | title=Playing to an Audience of One, Dan Patrick Doesn’t Need Your Approval | url=https://www.mystatesman.com/news/state--regional-govt--politics/playing-audience-one-dan-patrick-doesn-need-your-approval/SCZ3uqoz7sXdstOYvXyxcP/ | date=February 16, 2018 | publisher=''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' | accessdate=March 6, 2018}} After this, Patrick's faith became an important part of his life, and he considered going into Christian ministry for a time. Patrick, an [[Evangelicalism|evangelical Christian]], is a member of various Christian organizations, including [[Fellowship of Christian Athletes]] and the [[International Bible Society]],{{cite web | title=Dan Patrick's Biography | url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/57986/dan-patrick#.WFgdA2wzVPY | publisher=[[Project Vote Smart]] | accessdate=December 19, 2016}} and has served as guest pastor of his church, the [[Second Baptist Church Houston]].{{cite web | title=Meet Dan | url=http://danpatrick.org/meet-dan/ | publisher=''danpatrick.org'' | accessdate=December 18, 2017}} He is very outspoken about his Christian faith, and he stated in his inauguration speech upon becoming lieutenant governor that "I respect all faiths and religions, but I am a Christian first, a conservative second and a Republican third, and I praise Jesus for this moment and this day." Patrick was baptized in the [[Jordan River]] during a trip to [[Israel]] in 2016.{{cite web | last1=Wise | first1=Hannah | title=Texas Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick Baptized in Jordan River During Visit to Israel | url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2016/05/01/texas-lt-gov-dan-patrick-baptized-in-jordan-river-during-visit-to-israel | date=May 1, 2016 | publisher=''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' | accessdate=February 25, 2018}} ==Electoral history== ===2014=== {{Election box begin no change | title=Texas lieutenant gubernatorial {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{refimprove|date=October 2015}} {{for|the 2004 film|Deed Poll (film)}} A '''deed poll''' (plural: '''deeds poll''') is a [[Law|legal]] document binding only to a single person or several persons acting jointly to express an active intention. It is, strictly speaking, not a [[contract]] because it binds only one [[party (law)|party]] and expresses an intention instead of a promise.
==Use for changing name== {{main|Deed of change of name}} The most common use is a [[name change]] through a [[deed of change of name]] {{fact|date=July 2014}} (often referred to simply as a ''deed poll''). Deeds poll are used for this purpose in countries including the [[United Kingdom]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Singapore]]. In the UK, a deed poll can also be used to change a child's name, as long as everyone with parental responsibility for the child consents to it and the child does not object to it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Changing your name|url=http://www.adviceguide.org.uk/england/relationships_e/relationships_birth_certificates_and_changing_your_name_e/changing_your_name.htm|website=AdviceGuide UK|accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref> The child's parents execute the deed poll on the child's behalf. In some other jurisdictions, a person may simply start using a new name without any formal legal process. The usual requirements are that the new name must be used exclusively and that the change must not be made with intent to [[fraud|defraud]]. In [[Australia]], prior to 1 November 2000<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.justice.tas.gov.au/bdm/changeofname/deed_poll_searches_(pre-2000)|title=Births Deaths and Marriages : Deed poll searches (pre-2000)|website=www.justice.tas.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-02-05}}</ref>, name change was formerly accomplished by deed poll but now is done by completing a Change of Name form.
The UK Government provides a free web-based service to advise individuals on changing name using a deed poll. Several websites have been established that charge for this service, some of which appear to be from government agencies. However, these have no official status.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ferguson|first1=Donna|title=Deed poll websites to avoid|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2013/jun/29/deed-poll-websites-avoid|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 June 2013|location=London}}</ref>
==Other uses== Another common use is to [[Partition (law)|partition]] land into different sections. For example, a piece of land may be partitioned (or carved out) by a deed poll into Section A and the Remaining Portion thereof. This form of deed poll is commonly used in [[Hong Kong]].
A deed poll may also be used (in England and Wales) for clergy of the Church of England to relinquish their [[holy orders]].
==Origin of the term== The term "deed", also known in this context as a "specialty", is common to signed written undertakings not supported by consideration: the seal (even if not a literal wax seal but only a notional one referred to by the execution formula, "signed, sealed and delivered", or even merely "executed as a deed") is deemed to be the consideration necessary to support the obligation. "Poll" is an [[Archaism|archaic]] legal term referring to documents with straight edges; these distinguished a deed binding only one person from one affecting more than a single person (an "[[indenture]]", so named during the time when such agreements would be written out repeatedly on a single sheet, then the copies separated by being irregularly torn or cut, i.e. "indented", so that each party had a document with corresponding tears, to discourage [[forgery]]).

{{Infobox person | name = Edward Trusted Bennett | image = Edward T. Bennett psychical researcher.png |birth_date = July 1, 1831 |birth_place = [[London]] |death_date = November 16, 1908 |death_place = [[Port Isaac]], Cornwall | occupation = [[Botanist]], [[Parapsychology|psychical researcher]]}}
'''Edward Trusted Bennett''' (July 1, 1831 - November 16, 1908), best known as '''Edward T. Bennett''' was a British [[botanist]] and [[Parapsychology|psychical researcher]].
==Biography==
Bennett was born in [[London]]. His younger brother was the botanist [[Alfred William Bennett]]. As a young man he collected plant specimens in [[Cornwall]] and the [[New Forest]].<ref>Anonymous. (1909). [https://archive.org/stream/mobot31753002398524#page/39/mode/2up ''Book-Notes, News, Etc'']. ''[[Journal of Botany, British and Foreign]]'' 47: 39.</ref><ref>Desmond, Ray. (1994). ''Dictionary of British and Irish Botanists and Horticulturists''. Taylor & Francis Ltd. p. 65. {{ISBN|0-85066-843-3}}</ref> Bennett was the last [[Quakers|Quaker]] in Britain to be disowned for holding different theological opinions. In 1873, he was disowned for supporting the heretical views of [[Charles Voysey (theist)|Charles Voysey]].<ref>Helmstadter, Richard J. (1997). ''Freedom and Religion in the Nineteenth Century''. Stanford University Press. p. 147.</ref><ref>Kennedy, Thomas C. (2001). ''British Quakerism, 1860-1920: The Transformation of a Religious Community''. Oxford University Press. p. 81. {{ISBN|0-19-827035-6}}</ref>
He was a member of the [[British National Association of Spiritualists]] and the first secretary of the [[Society for Psychical Research]].<ref>Oppenheim, Janet. (1985). ''The Other World: Spiritualism and Psychical Research in England, 1850-1914''. Cambridge University Press. p. 425. {{ISBN|0-521-26505-3}}</ref> From 1882 to 1902 he worked as an assistant secretary for the Society.<ref>Crabtree. Adam. (1988). ''Animal Magnetism, Early Hypnotism, and Psychical Research, 1766-1925: An Annotated Bibliography''. Kraus International Publications. p. 349.</ref>
He died in [[Port Isaac]], Cornwall.
==Publications== *[https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/008994980 ''The Poetical Work of George Barlow: A Study''] (1903) *[https://archive.org/details/societyforpsychi00benn ''The Society for Psychical Research: Its Rise & Progress & a Sketch of its Work''] (1903) *''Twenty Years of Psychical Research: 1882-1901'' (1904) *[https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/100472988 ''Automatic Speaking and Writing: A Study''] (1905) *[https://archive.org/details/physicalphenomen00bennrich ''The Physical Phenomena Popularly Classed Under the Head of Spiritualism''] (1907) [With a brief introduction by [[Oliver Lodge]]] *''The Direct Phenomena of Spiritualism'' (1908) *[https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006875185 ''Psychic Phenomena''] (1909) [With a foreword by [[Oliver Lodge]]]

{{Infobox person | name = Francisco Cáceres | image = | birth_place = [[El Salvador]] | years_active = 2006 - present | awards = 2014 & 2015 Daytime [[Emmy Award|Emmy]] | website = [http://www.francisco-caceres.com www.francisco-caceres.com] }} '''Francisco Cáceres''' is a two-time [[Emmy Award|Emmy]] winner TV host and producer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.laprensagrafica.com/2015/04/28/francisco-caceres-gana-segundo-emmy|title=Francisco Cáceres gana segundo Emmy|last=Gráfica|first=La Prensa|website=La Prensa Gráfica|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> He’s currently the Film Expert for [[Telemundo]]’s national morning show, [[Un Nuevo Dia (TV Series)|Un Nuevo Día]];<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elsalvador.com/articulo//francisco-caceres-nueva-estrella-telemundo-31471|title=Francisco Cáceres, la nueva estrella de Telemundo|last=|first=|date=|newspaper=elsalvador.com|access-date=2016-11-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> and the Host of his own weekly film show on [[DirecTV]] Latin America, OnCINEMA.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.elsalvador.com/articulo/entretenimiento/francisco-caceres-conquista-meca-del-cine-estadounidense-57983|title=Francisco Cáceres conquista la meca del cine estadounidense|last=|first=|date=|newspaper=elsalvador.com|access-date=2016-11-07|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> He’s also the Main Anchor for [[Fandango Media|Fandango]] Cine, the Spanish version of the popular Movie-Ticketing website Fandango.com.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fandango.com/movie-news/get-to-know-fandango-cine-your-no-1-all-spanish-movie-site-734258|title=Get to Know Fandango Cine, Your No. 1 All-Spanish Movie Site|date=2013-02-25|newspaper=Fandango|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref>
== Early life == Francisco Cáceres was born and raised in [[Santa Ana, El Salvador|Santa Ana]], [[El Salvador]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://elmundo.com.sv/me-aterraba-no-cumplir-mis-suenos-francisco-caceres |title=Noticias de El Salvador {{!}} Diario El Mundo » "Me aterraba no cumplir mis sueños" , Francisco Cáceres |date=2013-01-06 |access-date=2016-11-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106083017/http://elmundo.com.sv/me-aterraba-no-cumplir-mis-suenos-francisco-caceres |archivedate=2013-01-06 |df= }}</ref> At the age of 18, he moved to San Salvador to attend [[Central American University]] UCA. There, he graduated with honors as the first of his class with a Bachelor’s Degree in Communications.
In 2009, he moved to Madrid to earn a Master’s Degree in Filmmaking from Madrid Film School (ECAM) and [[King Juan Carlos University]].
He speaks Spanish, English and French.
== Professional career == He started his television career at the age of 20 in El Salvador, hosting and producing various entertainment TV and radio shows like Ticket con Francisco Cáceres,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.laprensagrafica.com/fama/espectaculos/219169-su-meta-ser-productor-ejecutivo.html|title=Su meta: ser productor ejecutivo|last=Gráfica|first=La Prensa|newspaper=La Prensa Gráfica|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> his own weekly film show that started on [[Telecorporación Salvadoreña]] and eventually expanded to [[Cinemark Theatres|Cinemark]] movie theaters in the rest of Central America and Colombia.
In 2013, he moved to [[Miami]] to work at [[Telemundo]], as the Network's Film Expert. That same year he started hosting a Film Review Show on [[DirecTV]] Latin America, OnCINEMA, that airs in 13 countries in South America.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.telemundo.com/talentos/francisco-caceres|title=Francisco Cáceres|newspaper=Telemundo|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref>
His experience as a correspondent includes coverage of the [[Academy Awards]], the [[Grammy Award|Grammys]], [[Latin Grammy Award|Latin Grammys]], and the [[Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]], [[Sundance Film Festival|Sundance]] and [[Toronto International Film Festival|Toronto Film Festivals]]. Besides, he has interviewed some of the most important personalities in entertainment, including [[George Clooney]], [[Nicole Kidman]], [[Bono]], [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Woody Allen]], [[Penélope Cruz]], [[Jennifer Lopez|Jennifer López]], Latin superstars [[Café Tacuba|Café Tacvba]] and [[Calle 13 (band)|Calle 13]], among others.
Behind the scenes, he has directed, written and produced 2 short films, 20 TV Spots and he has created 5 TV Shows in different genres (entertainment, sports, musicals and game shows). Furthermore, he presented his short film Bebé a primera vista (Baby at first sight) at the Short Film Corner of the Cannes Film Festival.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.laprensagrafica.com/fama/espectaculos/118705-caceres-muestra-bebe-a-primera-vista-en-cannes.html|title=Cáceres Muestra Bebé A Primera Vista En Cannes|last=Gráfica|first=La Prensa|date=19 May 2010|newspaper=La Prensa Gráfica|access-date=2016-11-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107161611/http://www.laprensagrafica.com/fama/espectaculos/118705-caceres-muestra-bebe-a-primera-vista-en-cannes.html|archive-date=7 November 2016|dead-url=yes}}</ref>
== Awards == Francisco was recognized with 3 [[Daytime Emmy Award]]s in 2014, 2015 & 2017 as Correspondent and Producer of the Best Morning Show in Spanish, [[Telemundo]]’s [[Un Nuevo Dia (TV Series)|Un Nuevo Día]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://emmyonline.com/day_42nd_telecast_winners |title=THE NATIONAL ACADEMY OF TELEVISION ARTS & SCIENCES ANNOUNCES WINNERS FOR THE 42nd ANNUAL DAYTIME EMMY® AWARDS {{!}} The Emmy Awards - The National Academy of Television Arts & Sciences |website=emmyonline.com |access-date=2016-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Y5mabgB9?url=http://emmyonline.com/day_42nd_telecast_winners |archivedate=2015-04-27 |df= }}</ref>
== References == <references />
