([[Pompano Beach, Florida]]) |college=[[LSU Tigers football|LSU]] |draftyear=2011 |draftround=1 |draftpick=5 |pastteams= * [[Arizona Cardinals ]] ({{NFL Year|2011}}–present) |status=Active |highlights= * 7× [[Pro Bowl]] ([[2012 Pro Bowl|2011]]–[[2018 Pro Bowl|2017]]) * 3× First-team [[All-Pro]] ([[2011 All-Pro Team|2011]], [[2013 All-Pro Team|2013]], [[2015 All-Pro Team|2015]]) * [[Chuck Bednarik Award]] (2010) * [[Jim Thorpe Award]] (2010) * 2× First-team [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]] ([[2009 College Football All-America Team|2009]], [[2010 College Football All-America Team|2010]]) * First-team All-[[Southeastern Conference|SEC]] ([[2010 All-SEC football team|2010]]) * Second-team All-SEC ([[2009 All-SEC football team|2009]]) * ''[[USA Today]]'' High School All-American ([[2007 USA Today All-USA high school football team|2007]]) |statleague=NFL |statweek=7 |statseason=2018 |statlabel1=[[Tackle (football move)|Total tackles]] |statvalue1=366 |statlabel2=[[Pass deflections]] |statvalue2=74 |statlabel3=[[Interceptions]] |statvalue3=23 |statlabel4=[[Fumble|Forced fumbles]] |statvalue4=1 |statlabel5=[[Fumble|Fumble recoveries]] |statvalue5=2 |statlabel6=[[Touchdown|Total touchdowns]] |statvalue6=5 |nflnew=patrickpeterson/2495504 |pfr=PetePa00 }} '''Patrick De'mon Peterson Jr.''' (born July 11, 1990) is an [[American football]] [[cornerback]] for the [[Arizona Cardinals]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL). He played college football at [[Louisiana State University]] (LSU), where he won the [[Chuck Bednarik Award]] as the best defensive player in the country, the [[Jim Thorpe Award]] as the best defensive back, and was unanimously recognized as an [[College Football All-America Team|All-American]]. He was selected fifth overall by the Cardinals in the first round of the [[2011 NFL Draft]]. Peterson has been invited to the [[Pro Bowl]] in each of his first seven seasons in the NFL.https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00.htm ==Early years== Peterson was born in [[Pompano Beach, Florida]] on July 11, 1990. He attended [[Blanche Ely High School]], where he played [[running back]] and [[defensive back]] for the Blanche Ely Mighty Tigers [[high school football]] team.{{Cite news |url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/highschool/football/broward/fl-patrick-peterson-football-camp-0630-20130629-story.html |title=Former Blanche Ely star Peterson hosts youth camp in Pompano Beach |last=Cabrera |first=Christy |work=Sun-Sentinel.com |access-date=2018-02-18 |language=en-US}} In his junior campaign, he recorded 11 total touchdowns on offense, while recording seven interceptions and 54 tackles on defense. He also returned three kick-offs for touchdowns and added 10 rushes for 213 yards. As a senior, Peterson compiled 733 yards rushing and 11 touchdowns (9 rushing, one kick return and one punt return). Defensively, he had 21 tackles and five interceptions. Besides numerous All-American team selections, Peterson was named Defensive Player of the Year by ''[[USA Today]]'' and played in the 2008 [[U.S. Army All-American Bowl]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.goarmy.com/events/all-american-bowl/all-american-alumni.html |title=U.S. Army All-American Bowl Alumni |website=goarmy.com |access-date=2018-02-18}} He was also on the school's [[track & field]] team, where he ran the [[100 meters]] in 10.92 seconds and the [[200 meters]] in 22.24 seconds. He was also a member of the [[4 x 100 metres relay|4 × 100 m relay]] (41.41 s) squad.[https://www.trackingfootball.com/players/patrick-peterson-5398/ Patrick Peterson | Louisiana State | Cardinals CB/KR]. Trackingfootball.com. Retrieved on November 5, 2015. ===Recruiting=== A consensus five-star prospect by all major [[Recruiting (college athletics)|recruiting]] services, Peterson was rated as the nation's fifth best overall player by [[Rivals.com]] and No. 8 by ''[[ESPN]]''. Prior to his senior season, he verbally committed to play for the [[University of Miami]], but continued to look at other schools.{{Citation |title=Ely's Johnson: UM's for me |newspaper=South Florida Sun-Sentinel |date=April 5, 2007 |last=Kelly |first=Omar }} By November 2007, Peterson had reopened his recruiting process and acknowledged interest in [[University of Georgia|Georgia]], [[University of Southern California|USC]], [[University of Florida|Florida]], and LSU.{{Citation |url=http://florida.scout.com/2/698515.html |title=Johnson Looking at Four Schools |last=Higdon |first=Jason |date=November 5, 2007 |work=Scout.com }} He later dropped Georgia and USC from his list and added [[Florida State University|Florida State]],{{Citation |url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/preps/2008-01-04-seniors-colleges_N.htm |title=Seniors set to name college picks at U.S. Army All-American Bowl |date=January 5, 2008 |first=Jim |last=Halley |work=USA Today}} but eventually announced his decision to attend LSU at the U.S. Army All-American Bowl.{{Citation |title=Ely's Johnson selects LSU |newspaper=Miami Herald |date=January 6, 2008 }} ==College career== Peterson attended [[Louisiana State University]], where he played for coach [[Les Miles]]'s [[LSU Tigers football]] team from 2008 to 2010.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/patrick-peterson-1.html |title=Patrick Peterson College Stats |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} ===Freshman year=== One of the most decorated high school players to ever attend LSU, Peterson played 13 games as a [[true freshman]]. On November 8, against SEC West rival Alabama, he had his first collegiate interception.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2008-11-08-louisiana-state.html |title=Alabama at Louisiana State Box Score, November 8, 2008 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He started the final four games of season, including the [[2008 Chick-fil-A Bowl|Chick-fil-A Bowl]] win over [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets football|Georgia Tech]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2008-12-31-georgia-tech.html |title=Chick-fil-A Bowl - LSU at Georgia Tech Box Score, December 31, 2008 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson finished the season with 41 tackles, one interception, and three pass breakups, while also adding a forced fumble and a quarterback hurry.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/patrick-peterson-1/gamelog/2008/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2008 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} ===Sophomore year=== In his sophomore season, Peterson emerged as one of the top defensive backs in the [[Southeastern Conference]]. On September 26, against Mississippi State, he had a 37-yard interception return for a touchdown.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2009-09-26-mississippi-state.html |title=LSU at Mississippi State Box Score, September 26, 2009 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In a game against standout wide receiver [[A. J. Green]] of [[University of Georgia Bulldogs|Georgia]],{{Cite news |url=http://jacksonville.com/sports/college/georgia-bulldogs/2010-09-29/story/georgia-receiver-aj-green-says-he-lost-sleep-over |title=Georgia receiver A.J. Green says he lost sleep over suspension |newspaper=The Florida Times-Union |date=September 29, 2010 }} Peterson was able to hold Green to just four catches.{{cite web|author=Football |url=http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=1382573 |title=Patrick Peterson Bio – LSUsports.net – The Official Web Site of LSU Tigers Athletics |publisher=LSUsports.net |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2010}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2009-10-03-georgia.html |title=LSU at Georgia Box Score, October 3, 2009 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} By mid-season, Peterson tied for fourth in the league with seven passes defended, and was named the SEC's "Most Improved Player" by ESPN's Chris Low.{{Citation |url=http://espn.go.com/blog/sec/post/_/id/4944/a-few-more-midseason-awards-in-the-sec |title=A few more mid-season awards in the SEC |date=October 22, 2009 |work=ESPN |last=Low |first=Chris }} Another highly anticipated match-up occurred when Peterson went against [[Julio Jones]] of [[University of Alabama football|Alabama]].{{Cite news |url=http://www.nola.com/lsu/index.ssf/2009/11/lsu_cornerback_patrick_peterso_1.html |title=LSU cornerback Patrick Peterson will try to stop Alabama's Julio Jones |newspaper=The Times-Picayune |first=James |last=Varney |date=November 4, 2009 }} Peterson's LSU Tigers were ranked 9th in the country and traveled to face [[Nick Saban]] and the #1 ranked Crimson Tide. The Tigers were down by six points late in the fourth quarter when Peterson stepped in front of a pass from [[Greg McElroy]] to Julio Jones for what seemed like an interception. Multiple [[CBS]] camera angles showed that Peterson was able to get at least one foot in bounds.{{cite web |url=http://www.scoresreport.com/2009/11/09/screenshots-of-patrick-pattersons-interception/ |title=Screenshots of Patrick Peterson’s interception |first=John |last=Paulsen |date=November 9, 2009 |work=The Scores Report }} However, even after review, the SEC officiating crew called the pass incomplete, saying that Peterson was not able to get any foot in bounds. Alabama would go on to kick a field goal on that drive and won 24–15. The missed interception call quickly became infamous and was debated by many media outlets.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2009-11-07-alabama.html |title=LSU at Alabama Box Score, November 7, 2009 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}}{{cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/andy_staples/11/07/lsu.alabama/index.html |title=LSU loss marred by missed-INT call - Andy Staples - SI.com |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=November 7, 2009 |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} Peterson finished 2009 with 52 tackles.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/players/patrick-peterson-1/gamelog/2009/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2009 Game Log |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} His 43 solo tackles were second on the team behind linebacker [[Kelvin Sheppard]]. Peterson returned an interception for a touchdown against [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State]], and he returned a blocked field goal against [[Ole Miss Rebels football|Ole Miss]] for a touchdown. He was also named a 2009 Second-Team All-American by ''[[The Sporting News]]'', a 2009 First-Team All-SEC performer by ESPN, and a 2009 Second-Team All-SEC performer by the AP. ===Junior year=== Peterson was named to the preseason watch lists for the [[Nagurski Award]], the [[Thorpe Award]], the [[Ronnie Lott Award]], the [[Walter Camp Award]], and the [[Chuck Bednarik Award]]. It was announced during the summer of 2010 that Peterson would begin returning punts and kickoffs due to his size, speed, and athleticism. With this added dimension to his game, and his dominance as a cornerback, Peterson began being mentioned as a [[dark horse]] for the 2010 Heisman Trophy award, presented to the best college football player every year.{{Citation |url=http://promo.espn.go.com/espn/contests/nissan/heisman/voteHeisman |title=Heisman Vote 2010 – presented by Nissan |work=ESPN |accessdate=September 29, 2010 }} Only one defensive player has ever won the Heisman Trophy, [[Charles Woodson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-20106733.html |title=University of Michigan's Charles Woodson named Heisman Trophy winner. (first defensive player to win)(Brief Article) – Jet | HighBeam Research – FREE trial |publisher=Highbeam.com |date=December 29, 1997 |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} Peterson began his Heisman campaign against [[University of North Carolina Tar Heels|North Carolina]] in the 2010 Chick-fil-A Kickoff. The Tigers won 30–24 and Peterson was terrific.{{Cite news |url=http://www.neworleans.com/sports/lsu/467939-shepard-peterson-give-lsu-win-over-unc-.html |work=LSU News |title=Shepard, Peterson Give LSU Win Over UNC |date=September 4, 2010 }} In his debut as a returner, Peterson had a school-record 257 yards returning punts and kickoffs, 244 yards coming in the first half. He returned a punt 87 yards for a touchdown and consistently gave the Tiger's offense good field position. His 257-yard performance ranks second all-time in the SEC behind [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State's]] Nick Turner and his 266-yard performance. Peterson was named Special Teams Player of the Week for his performance.{{cite web|author=Football |url=http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=204988986&SPID=2164&SPSID=27815 |title=Peterson Named Special Teams Player of the Week – LSUsports.net – The Official Web Site of LSU Tigers Athletics |publisher=LSUsports.net |date=September 6, 2010 |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} He was also named the Lott IMPACT Player of the Week.{{cite web|author=Football |url=http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=204990353&SPID=2164&SPSID=27815 |title=Peterson Named Lott Player of the Week – LSUsports.net – The Official Web Site of LSU Tigers Athletics |publisher=LSUsports.net |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=October 29, 2010}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-09-04-louisiana-state.html |title=North Carolina vs Louisiana State Box Score, September 4, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson had two punt returns against [[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt]] for 8 yards in week two as the Tigers rolled past the Commodores. He also returned two kickoffs for 51 yards, to go along with one tackle.{{cite web|url=http://www.lsusports.net/src/data/lsu/assets/docs/fb/10stats/indgbg.htm?DB_OEM_ID=5200#IGBG.RET |title=LSU – Individual Game-by-Game Summaries |publisher=Lsusports.net |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2010}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-09-11-vanderbilt.html |title=LSU at Vanderbilt Box Score, September 11, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In week three of the 2010 season, the 2–0 Tigers hosted 1–1 Mississippi State for LSU's first home game of the year. The Tiger defense suffocated Mississippi State's offense and Peterson strengthened his campaign with two acrobatic interceptions for LSU. He also returned one kickoff 39 yards and one punt 2 yards to go along with four solo tackles.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-09-18-louisiana-state.html |title=Mississippi State at Louisiana State Box Score, September 18, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson entertained the home crowd again in week four against Top-25 foe [[West Virginia Mountaineers football|West Virginia]]. With the game tied 0–0 early in the first quarter, West Virginia went to attempt a mid-range field goal and Peterson was able to leap from behind the line of scrimmage and block the kick. The Tiger defense forced West Virginia to punt later in the half. Peterson fielded the punt on his own 40-yard line and raced 60-yards up the middle of the field for a touchdown and a 17–0 LSU lead. Peterson struck the Heisman pose in the North end zone of [[Tiger Stadium (LSU)|Tiger Stadium]], drawing a 15-yard unsportsmanlike conduct penalty. Peterson was almost single-handedly responsible for 10 points in the game that ended with LSU winning 20–14. The national sports media began comparing Peterson to Woodson, who actually had worse statistics than Peterson through his first four games during his Heisman winning season.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/story/14015882/looking-for-heisman-look-no-further-than-lsus-peterson |title=Looking for Heisman? Look no further than LSU's Peterson – NCAA Football |publisher=CBSSports.com |date=September 26, 2010 |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} Peterson was again named SEC Special Teams Player of the Week.[http://www.miamiherald.com/2010/09/27/1844731/sec-honors-newton-lester-and-peterson.html ]{{dead link|date=October 2010}} He also recorded 1 solo tackle.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-09-25-louisiana-state.html |title=West Virginia at Louisiana State Box Score, September 25, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Week five saw the LSU Tigers take on the [[Tennessee Volunteers football|Tennessee Volunteers]]. Peterson and the LSU defense limited Tennessee to 217 yards of offense and the Tigers won 16–14.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/sec |title=Sec Blog – Espn |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} Peterson recorded 1 solo tackle and 3 assisted tackles. He had 3 [[punt return]]s for 30 yards and 3 [[kickoff return]]s for 64 yards. The LSU Tigers improved to 5–0 and 3–0 in the SEC with the victory over the Volunteers.{{Cite web |url= https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-10-02-louisiana-state.html |title= Tennessee at Louisiana State Box Score, October 2, 2010 |website= College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language= en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson's efforts helped the Tigers to a No. 12 ranking in the [[AP Top 25|Associated Press Top 25]] as well as a No. 9 ranking in the [[USA Today Coaches Poll|USA Today Coaches Poll Top 25]].{{cite web |url= http://espn.go.com/college-football/rankings |title=2010 NCAA College Football Polls and Rankings for Week 9 – ESPN |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} Through week 5 of the 2010 season, he was 3rd in Division 1-A in punt return average at 23.6 yards per attempt (12 for 283), 1st in punt return touchdowns with 2, and 22nd in kickoff return average at 28.2 yards per attempt. Peterson was also tied for 30th in the country with two interceptions.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/statistics |title=2010 NCAA College Football Stats – ESPN |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} He was in the top five of most straw polls regarding the 2010 Heisman Trophy.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/heisman |title=College Football Heisman Watch |publisher=CBSSports.com |date=July 28, 2010 |accessdate=October 29, 2010}} In an effort to jumpstart the struggling offense for the Tigers, Peterson practiced as a [[wide receiver]] and a [[running back]] on offense. On October 9, against the Florida Gators, Peterson had four kick returns for 106 net yards, one punt return, and one total tackle in the 33–29 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-10-09-florida.html |title=LSU at Florida Box Score, October 9, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In the next game, against McNeese State, he had two kick returns for 63 net yards and two punt returns for 34 net yards to go along with one tackle.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-10-16-louisiana-state.html |title=McNeese State at Louisiana State Box Score, October 16, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In the following game, against Auburn, he had four kick returns for 99 net yards, two punt returns for 18 net yards, and three total tackles.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-10-23-auburn.html |title=LSU at Auburn Box Score, October 23, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On November 6, against Alabama, he had two kick returns for 45 net yards, two punt returns for 22 net yards, eight total tackles, and three passes defended in the 24–21 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-11-06-louisiana-state.html |title=Alabama at Louisiana State Box Score, November 6, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} The next week, against Louisiana–Monroe, he had three punt returns for 31 net yards, one total tackle, and an interception that was returned 85 yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-11-13-louisiana-state.html |title=Louisiana-Monroe at Louisiana State Box Score, November 13, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In the following game, against Ole Miss, he had four kick returns for 121 net yards, three punt returns for 30 net yards, four total tackles, and one interception.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-11-20-louisiana-state.html |title=Ole Miss at Louisiana State Box Score, November 20, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On November 27, against Arkansas, he had four kick returns for 163 net yards, three total tackles, and one pass defensed.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2010-11-27-arkansas.html |title=LSU at Arkansas Box Score, November 27, 2010 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In his final collegiate game, the Cotton Bowl against Texas A&M, he had three kick returns for 81 net yards to go along with six total tackles.{{Cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/cfb/boxscores/2011-01-07-louisiana-state.html |title=Cotton Bowl - Texas A&M vs Louisiana State Box Score, January 7, 2011 |website=College Football at Sports-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Following the season, he was a first-team All-SEC selection, and was recognized as a unanimous first-team All-American.''2011 NCAA Football Records Book'', [https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120516105427/http://fs.ncaa.org/Docs/stats/football_records/2011/Awards.pdf Award Winners], National Collegiate Athletic Association, Indianapolis, Indiana, p. 12 (2011). Retrieved June 30, 2012. ==Professional career== Coming out of LSU in 2011, Peterson was a projected first round pick by NFL draft experts and scouts. He was a consensus top five pick and was thought to be the best player in the draft by multiple analysts.{{cite web|URL=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/brian-billick-ranks-top-50-2011-nfl-draft-prospects-041911| title=Billick ranks top 50 NFL draft prospects| accessdate=October 23, 2017| website=foxsports.com| author=Brian Billick| date=April 19, 2011}} Peterson attended the NFL combine and completed all of the required combine drills. On March 14, 2011, he participated at LSU's pro day and opted to stand on his combine numbers and only perform positional drills for scouts and team representatives. [[2011 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers']] head coach [[Mike Tomlin]], [[2011 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers']] head coach [[Ron Rivera]], and [[2011 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints']] head coach [[Sean Payton]] were among the team representatives that attended LSU's pro day to scout Peterson, [[Kelvin Sheppard]], [[Drake Nevis]], [[Joseph Barksdale]], [[Stevan Ridley]], [[Lazarius Levingston]], [[Terrence Toliver]], and multiple others.{{cite web|URL=http://blogs.nfl.com/2011/03/14/lsus-peterson-generates-no-1-worthy-buzz/| title=LSU’s Peterson generates No. 1-worthy buzz| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=blogs.Nfl.com| author=Gil Brandt}} He was ranked the top cornerback prospect in the draft by NFL analyst [[Mike Mayock]], NFLDraftScout.com, [[Foxsports]] analyst [[Brian Billick]], and ''[[Sports Illustrated]]''.{{cite web|URL=https://www.bigcatcountry.com/platform/amp/2011/2/11/1987963/mike-mayocks-updated-top-5-2011-nfl-draft-rankings| title=Mike Mayock's Updated Top 5 2011 NFL Draft Rankings| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=bigcatcountry.com| author=Alfie Crow| date=May 11, 2011}}{{cite web|URL=https://www.si.com/nfl/2011/02/16/2011-nfl-draft-prospects| title=2011 NFL Draft: Ranking top 50 prospects heading into combine| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=si.com| date=February 16, 2011}}{{cite web|URL=http://www.nfldraftscout.com/ratings/dsprofile.php?pyid=83210&draftyear=2011&genpos=CB| title=*Patrick Peterson, DS #1 CB, LSU| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=nfldraftscout.com}} {{nfl predraft | height ft = 6 | height in = 0¼ | weight = 219 | dash = 4.34 | ten split = 1.49 | twenty split = 2.44 | shuttle = 4.07 | cone drill = 6.58 | vertical = 38 | broad ft = 10 | broad in = 6 | bench = 15 | wonderlic = | arm span = 32 | hand span = 9¼ | note = All values from [[NFL Combine]] {{cite web|title=NFL Combine: Patrick Peterson|url=http://www.nfl.com/combine/profiles/patrick-peterson?id=2495504|website=NFL.com|accessdate=December 9, 2014}} }} The [[Arizona Cardinals]] selected Peterson in the first round (fifth overall) of the [[2011 NFL Draft]]. He was the first cornerback selected.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2011/draft.htm |title=2011 NFL Draft Listing |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} ===2011=== On July 30, 2011, the [[2011 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]] signed Peterson to a fully guaranteed four-year, $18.42 million contract that included a signing bonus of $11.90 million.{{cite web|URL=http://www.spotrac.com/nfl/arizona-cardinals/patrick-peterson-7720/| title=Spotrac.com: Patrick Peterson contract| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=spotrac.com}}[http://www.nfl.com/draft/story/09000d5d82104d44/article/signing-status-of-2011-nfl-draft-firstround-picks?module=HP11_content_stream Signing status of 2011 NFL Draft first-round picks]. NFL. July 27, 2011 On August 27, 2011, Peterson intercepted a pass from [[Philip Rivers]] and returned it for a touchdown on his first play in a preseason game against the [[2011 San Diego Chargers season|San Diego Chargers]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2011082759/2011/PRE3/chargers@cardinals |title=Watch San Diego Chargers vs. Arizona Cardinals [08/27/2011] - NFL.com |website=www.nfl.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Head coach [[Ken Whisenhunt]] named Peterson the starting cornerback, alongside [[Greg Toler]], to begin his rookie season. He started the [[2011 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals']] season-opener against the [[2011 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers]] and scored his first career touchdown after returning a punt for an 89-yards in the fourth quarter to win the game 28-21. Peterson also recorded five solo tackles during the game.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201109110crd.htm |title=Carolina Panthers at Arizona Cardinals - September 11th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} The following week, he recorded a season-high eight combined tackles as the Cardinals lost 21-22 to the [[2011 Washington Redskins season|Washington Redskins]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201109180was.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Washington Redskins - September 18th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On September 25, 2011, Peterson made one tackle, defended a pass, and made his first career interception, picking off a pass from [[2011 Seattle Seahawks season|Seattle Seahawks']] quarterback [[Tarvaris Jackson]] during a 10-13 loss.{{cite web|URL=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2011092512/2011/REG3/cardinals@seahawks| title=NFL Game Center: Week 3-2011: Arizona Cardinals @ Seattle Seahawks| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=NFL.com}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201109250sea.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Seattle Seahawks - September 25th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On November 6, 2011, during the overtime period, Peterson fielded a punt at the one-yard line, evaded several would-be tacklers, and returned it for the 99-yard touchdown in a 19-13 victory over the [[2011 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams]]. He also intercepted a flea-flicker pass from [[Sam Bradford]] intended for [[Brandon Lloyd]] an recorded three tackles and three pass deflections.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201111060crd.htm |title=St. Louis Rams at Arizona Cardinals - November 6th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In Week 14, he led the Cardinals with five solo tackles and made the first sack of his career on [[2011 San Francisco 49ers season|San Francisco 49ers']] quarterback [[Alex Smith]] during 21-19 victory for the Cardinals.{{cite web|URL=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2011121110/2011/REG14/49ers@cardinals| title=NFL Game Center: Week 14-2011: San Francisco 49ers @ Arizona Cardinals| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=NFL.com}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201112110crd.htm |title=San Francisco 49ers at Arizona Cardinals - December 11th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He tied the single-season record for punt return touchdowns with his fourth, accomplishing the feat against St. Louis on November 27.{{cite web|last=Mayer|first=Larry|url=http://www.chicagobears.com/news/article-1/Bears-set-to-battle-Cardinals-in-Arizona/2e5cd083-979e-4aaf-a5c3-aad4e9058f2c|title=Bears set to battle Cardinals in Arizona|publisher=[[Chicago Bears]]|date=December 23, 2012|accessdate=December 23, 2012}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201111270ram.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at St. Louis Rams - November 27th, 2011 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He became the only player in NFL history with four punt-return touchdowns of at least 80 yards in a single season. He finished his rookie season with a sack, 64 combined tackles (59 solo), two interceptions, 13 passes defended, and two fumble recoveries in 16 games and 16 starts. He also produced a rookie record 699 return yards for four touchdowns on 44 punt returns.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2011/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2011 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson was selected as a kick returner to the [[2012 Pro Bowl]] and was the only rookie to be selected to the 2011 All-Pro First Team. ===2012=== Peterson returned as the starting cornerback, opposite [[William Gay (cornerback)|William Gay]], to begin the {{NFL Year|2012}} season. On September 16, 2012, Peterson had one carry for 17-yards, three combined tackles, a pass deflection, and intercepted [[Tom Brady]] in a 20-18 victory over the [[2012 New England Patriots season|New England Patriots]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201209160nwe.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at New England Patriots - September 16th, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On December 16, 2012, he recorded a season-high seven combined tackles and intercepted [[2012 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions']] quarterback [[Matt Stafford]] in a 38-10 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201212160crd.htm |title=Detroit Lions at Arizona Cardinals - December 16th, 2012 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} The interception marked his seventh of the season.{{cite web|URL=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2012/| title=Sports-Reference: Patrick Peterson stats| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=sports-reference.com}} Peterson started all 16 games making 55 tackles with seven interceptions, 17 passes defended, and a NFL-leading five fumble recoveries. He also had 51 punt returns producing 426 return yards, three receptions for 11 receiving yards, and two carries for 13 rushing yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2012/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2012 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On December 26, 2012, it was announced that Peterson was voted to the [[2013 Pro Bowl]] as a cornerback. ===2013=== The Arizona Cardinals' new head coach [[Bruce Arians]] named Peterson the starting cornerback, opposite [[Jerraud Powers]], to begin the {{NFL year|2013}} season.{{cite web|URL=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/150/ARZ| title=Ourlads.com: Arizona Cardinals' depth chart: 09/05/2013| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=ourlads.com}} On September 15, 2013, Peterson caught one pass for 17-yards, threw a 17-yard pass to [[Kerry Taylor]], and recorded four solo tackles during a 25-21 win against the [[2013 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201309150crd.htm |title=Detroit Lions at Arizona Cardinals - September 15th, 2013 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} This made him the first defender to catch and complete a pass in the same game since the 1970 merger. On September 29, he recorded two solo tackles and intercepted two passes from [[2013 Tampa Bay Buccaneers season|Tampa Bay Buccaneers']] quarterback [[Mike Glennon]] during a 13-10 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201309290tam.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Tampa Bay Buccaneers - September 29th, 2013 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}}{{cite web|URL=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2013092907/2013/REG4/cardinals@buccaneers| title=NFL Game Center: Week 4-2013: Arizona Cardinals @ Tampa Bay Buccaneers| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=NFL.com}} It was the first game of Peterson's career with multiple interceptions. In Week 14, Peterson collected a season-high seven combined tackles in a 37-34 victory over the [[2013 Tennessee Titans season|Tennessee Titans]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201312150oti.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Tennessee Titans - December 15th, 2013 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Although the Cardinals finished with a 10-6 record in their first year under Bruce Arians, they finished third in their division and did not qualify for a playoff berth.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/crd/2013.htm |title=2013 Arizona Cardinals Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson started all 16 games in 2013 and made 42 combined tackles (40 solo), three interceptions, 13 pass deflections, and two fumble recoveries. He also returned 33 punts for 198 return yards, had one kickoff return attempt for 18-yards, made six catches for 54 receiving yards, and had four carries for 21-yards.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2013/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2013 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He was selected for the [[2014 Pro Bowl]] as a cornerback, marking the third of his career. [[File:Patrick Peterson.jpg|200px|thumbnail|right|Peterson in the 2014 season.]] ===2014=== On July 29, 2014, the Arizona Cardinals signed Peterson to a five-year, $70 million contract extension with $48 million guaranteed and a $15.3 million signing bonus.{{cite web|work=NFL.com|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap2000000371301/article/patrick-peterson-cardinals-reach-fiveyear-extension|title=Patrick Peterson, Cardinals reach five-year extension|first=Gregg|last=Rosenthal|date=July 29, 2014|accessdate=July 30, 2014}} He began the season as the Arizona Cardinals' starting cornerback, opposite [[Antonio Cromartie]], and no longer had to handle return duties due to the arrival of [[Ted Ginn Jr.]] On November 9, 2014, he made two solo tackles and intercepted two passes from [[2014 St. Louis Rams season|St. Louis Rams']] quarterback [[Austin Davis]] during a 31-14 victory. He returned one interception for a 30-yard touchdown, marking the first defensive touchdown of his career.{{cite web|URL=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/2014110908/2014/REG10/rams@cardinals| title=NFL Game Center: Week 10-2014: St. Louis Rams @ Arizon Cardinals| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=NFL.com}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201411090crd.htm |title=St. Louis Rams at Arizona Cardinals - November 9th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On December 7, Peterson recorded a season-high eight combined tackles and sacked [[2014 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs']] quarterback [[Alex Smith]] in a 17-14 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201412070crd.htm |title=Kansas City Chiefs at Arizona Cardinals - December 7th, 2014 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He finished the {{NFL Year|2014}} season with 50 combined tackles (43 solo), eight pass deflections, three interceptions, a forced fumble, and three fumble recoveries in 16 games and 16 starts.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2014/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2014 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He was selected to the [[2015 Pro Bowl]] as a cornerback, marking his fourth straight appearance. The [[2014 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]] finished with an 11-5 record in 2014 and qualified for a playoff berth.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/crd/2014.htm |title=2014 Arizona Cardinals Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/years/2014 |title=2014 NFL Standings & Team Stats |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On January 3, 2015, Peterson played in his first career postseason game and recorded two combined tackles during a 16-27 lost to the Carolina Panthers in the [[National Football Conference|NFC]] Wildcard Game.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201501030car.htm |title=Wild Card - Arizona Cardinals at Carolina Panthers - January 3rd, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Shortly after the 2014 NFL season, Peterson announced that he had been diagnosed with [[diabetes]]. He stated that this affected his performance in the 2014 season, that he had the disease under control, and was ready for the 2015 season. ===2015=== Peterson was named the starting cornerback and had full-time punt return duties after the departure of Ted Ginn Jr.{{cite web|URL=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/176/ARZ| title=Ourlads.com: Arizona Cardinals' depth chart: 10/01/2015| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=ourlads.com}} On September 20, 2015, he recorded three solo tackles and intercepted [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] during a 48-23 win over the [[2015 Chicago Bears season|Chicago Bears]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201509200chi.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Chicago Bears - September 20th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In Week 5, he collected four combined tackles and intercepted a pass off [[Matthew Stafford]], as the [[2015 Arizona Cardinals season|Arizona Cardinals]] defeated the [[2015 Detroit Lions season|Detroit Lions]] 42-17.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201510110det.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Detroit Lions - October 11th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} The following game, he earned a season-high five solo tackles as the Cardinals were defeated by the [[2015 Pittsburgh Steelers season|Pittsburgh Steelers]] 13-25.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201510180pit.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Pittsburgh Steelers - October 18th, 2015 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Although he started all 16 games, Peterson finished with a career low 35 combined tackles (35 solo), eight pass deflections, and made two interceptions.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2015/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2015 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} The Arizona Cardinals finished first in the [[NFC West]] with a 13-3 record, receiving a playoff berth, home field advantage, and a first round bye week.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/crd/2015.htm |title=2015 Arizona Cardinals Statistics & Players |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} After defeating the [[2015 Green Bay Packers season|Green Bay Packers]] 26-20 in the NFC divisional round, the Cardinals went on the face the [[2015 Carolina Panthers season|Carolina Panthers]] in the [[NFC Championship]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201601160crd.htm |title=Divisional Round - Green Bay Packers at Arizona Cardinals - January 16th, 2016 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} Peterson recorded five combined tackles and returned an interception off [[Cam Newton]] for 70 yards, as the Cardinals lost 49–15.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201601240car.htm |title=NFC Championship - Arizona Cardinals at Carolina Panthers - January 24th, 2016 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He was selected to the [[2016 Pro Bowl]] as a cornerback, marking his fifth straight, and was voted third first-team All-Pro. He was also ranked 18th best player by his fellow NFL players on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2016]].[http://www.nfl.com/videos/nfl-top100-2016/0ap3000000671910/Top-100-Players-of-2016-No-18-Patrick-Peterson NFL Top 100 Players of 2016 - No. 18 Patrick Peterson] ===2016=== Peterson began the season as the starting cornerback, opposite [[Marcus Cooper]], with full time punt return duties being taken over by [[John Brown (wide receiver)|John Brown]] with Peterson returning sparingly throughout the season. On September 18, 2016, Peterson recorded four combined tackles and intercepted [[Jameis Winston]] during a 40-7 victory.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201609180crd.htm |title=Tampa Bay Buccaneers at Arizona Cardinals - September 18th, 2016 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} In Week 3, Peterson recorded four combined tackle and intercepted [[Tyrod Taylor]], catching the ball with one hand during a 18-33 loss to the [[2016 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]].[http://www.nfl.com/videos/nfl-cant-miss-plays/0ap3000000708766/Can-t-Miss-Play-Peterson-lays-out-for-one-handed-INT Can't-Miss Play: Patrick Peterson lays out for one-handed INT]{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201609250buf.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Buffalo Bills - September 25th, 2016 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On December 24, 2016, he collected a season-high six combined tackles in a 34-31 victory over the [[2016 Seattle Seahawks season|Seattle Seahawks]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201612240sea.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Seattle Seahawks - December 24th, 2016 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} He recorded 51 combined tackles (45 solo), six passes deflected, and three interceptions in 16 games and 16 starts.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2016/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2016 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On December 20, 2016, Peterson was selected to be in the [[2017 Pro Bowl]], along with teammates [[Larry Fitzgerald]] and [[David Johnson (running back)|David Johnson]]. This was Peterson's sixth straight Pro Bowl.{{cite web|URL=https://www..azcentral.com/amp/95676266| title=Arizona Cardinals Larry Fitzgerald, Patrick Peterson, David Johnson selected to Pro Bowl| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=azcentral.com| author=Kent Somers| date=December 20, 2016}} He was also ranked 19th by his peers on the [[NFL Top 100 Players of 2017]] as the highest ranked cornerback.[http://www.nfl.com/videos/nfl-top100-2017/0ap3000000816413/Top-100-Players-of-2017-No-19-Patrick-Peterson NFL Top 100 Players of 2017 - No. 19 Patrick Peterson] ===2017=== Peterson remained as the Cardinals' ''de facto'' starting cornerback with [[Justin Bethel]] after Marcus Cooper departed in [[free agency]]. In a Week 11 game against the [[Houston Texans]] Peterson got his first [[Interception]] of the season, a one handed grab off [[Tom Savage (American football)|Tom Savage]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ourlads.com/nfldepthcharts/archive/200/ARZ| title=Ourlads.com: Arizona Cardinals depth chart: 10/01/2017| accessdate=October 24, 2017| website=ourlads.com}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/boxscores/201711190htx.htm |title=Arizona Cardinals at Houston Texans - November 19th, 2017 |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} On December 19, 2017, Peterson was named to his seventh straight Pro Bowl.{{cite web|title=NFL announces 2018 Pro Bowl rosters|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap3000000895772/article/nfl-announces-2018-pro-bowl-rosters|website=NFL.com|date=December 19, 2017|accessdate=December 26, 2017}} Overall, he finished the 2017 season with 13 punt returns for 88 net yards, 34 total tackles, one fumble recovery, eight passes defensed, and one interception.{{Cite web |url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/P/PetePa00/gamelog/2017/ |title=Patrick Peterson 2017 Game Log |website=Pro-Football-Reference.com |language=en |access-date=2018-02-18}} ===2018=== In week 1 against the [[Washington Redskins]], Peterson had 1 tackle and 1 sack on quarterback [[Alex Smith]]. In week 2 against the [[Los Angeles Rams]], Peterson made 8 tackles and intercepted quarterback [[Jared Goff]] once. In week 7 against the [[Denver Broncos]], Peterson made 6 tackles and intercepted quarterback [[Case Keenum]] once. ===Career NFL statistics=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |- ! colspan="3" |Career statistics ! colspan="3" |Tackles !|Sacks ! colspan="3" |Interceptions ! colspan="5" |Other |- !Season !Team !Games !Solo !Ast !Total !Sack !Int !Yds !IntTD !DefTD !FFum !FRec !PD !Safety |- | {{nfly|2011}} |[[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |59 |5 |64 |1.0 |2 |1 |0 |0 |0 |2 |13 |0 |- | {{nfly|2012}} |[[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |52 |3 |55 |0 |7 |64 |0 |0 |0 |5 |16 |0 |- | {{nfly|2013}} |[[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |40 |2 |42 |0 |3 |59 |0 |0 |0 |2 |13 |0 |- | {{nfly|2014}} | [[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |43 |7 |50 |1.0 |3 |30 |1 |0 |0 |0 |7 |0 |- | {{nfly|2015}} | [[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |35 |0 |35 |0.0 |2 |41 |0 |0 |1 |0 |8 |0 |- | {{nfly|2016}} | [[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |45 |6 |51 |0.0 |3 |27 |0 |0 |0 |1 |6 |0 |- | {{nfly|2017}} | [[Arizona Cardinals|ARI]] |16 |30 |4 |34 |0.0 |1 |22 |0 |0 |0 |1 |8 |0 |- ! colspan="2" |Career !112 !304 !27 !331 !2.0 !21 !244 !1 !0 !1 !11 !71 !0 |} [http://espn.go.com/nfl/player/stats/_/id/13980/patrick-peterson Patrick Peterson Stats – Arizona Cardinals – ESPN]. Espn.go.com. ===NFL records=== * Most punt return touchdowns in a single season: 4 (2011) (tied with [[Devin Hester]], [[Jack Christiansen]], [[Rick Upchurch]]) * Longest overtime punt return touchdown: 99 yards ===Cardinals franchise records=== * Longest punt return touchdown: 99 (2011){{cite web | title= Chicago/St. Louis/Arizona Cardinals Kick & Punt Returns Single-Season Register | work= sports-reference.com | url=https://www.pro-football-reference.com/teams/crd/single-season-returns.htm |accessdate= }} * Most punt return touchdowns in a single season: 4 (2011) * Most punt return yards in a single season: 699 (2011) ==Personal life== Peterson went by the last name "Johnson" when he signed with LSU, but formally changed it to "Peterson" in August 2008. His parents are Patrick and Shandra Peterson of Fort Lauderdale, FL. He is a relative of NFL players [[Bryant McFadden]], [[Walter McFadden]], [[Sinorice Moss]] and [[Santana Moss]] (his maternal cousins).{{cite news|work=NYTimes.com|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/01/sports/football/01cardinals.html?_r=0|title=The Cardinals’ Top Pick Was Raised to Succeed|date=April 30, 2011|accessdate=March 16, 2014}} Peterson's younger brother, Avery Johnson (who has also changed his last name to "Peterson"), was a member of the [[ESPNU College Football|''ESPNU'']] 150 Watch List in 2012.[http://insider.espn.go.com/ncf/recruiting/player/news/_/id/105686/avery-johnson Avery Johnson 2012 Football Recruiting News – ESPN]. Insider.espn.go.com (September 2, 2010). Retrieved on 2015-11-05. On April 7, 2015, Peterson revealed he has [[type two diabetes]].{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nfl/story/_/id/13378731/patrick-peterson-arizona-cardinals-clarifies-type-2-diabetes|title=Bruce Arians: Diabetes caused Patrick Peterson's weight gain, struggles|date=August 4, 2015|first=Josh|last=Weinfuss}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.patrickpeterson21.com}} *[http://www.lsusports.net/ViewArticle.dbml?SPSID=27812&SPID=2164&DB_LANG=C&DB_OEM_ID=5200&ATCLID=1382573&Q_SEASON=2010 LSU Tigers bio] *[http://www.azcardinals.com/team/roster/Patrick-Peterson/e4ed9342-7c52-415f-a3e5-6b0cd789877b Arizona Cardinals bio] {{Arizona Cardinals roster navbox}} {{Navboxes | title = Patrick Peterson | list = {{USA Today DPOY}} {{Jim Thorpe Award}} {{Chuck Bednarik Award}} {{Southeastern Conference Football Player of the Year navbox}} {{2010 NCAA Division I FBS College Football Consensus All-Americans}} {{2011 NFL Draft}} {{CardinalsFirstPick}} {{Cardinals2011DraftPicks}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Peterson, Patrick}} [[Category:1990 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:All-American college football players]] [[Category:American football cornerbacks]] [[Category:American football return specialists]] [[Category:Arizona Cardinals players]] [[Category:Blanche Ely High School alumni]] [[Category:LSU Tigers football players]] [[Category:National Conference Pro Bowl players]] [[Category:People with diabetes mellitus type 2]] [[Category:Players of American football from Florida]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] [[Category:Unconferenced Pro Bowl players]]

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Paul Nabor | image = | caption = | landscape = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Alfonso Palacio | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1928|1|26|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Punta Gorda, Belize|Punta Gorda]], [[British Honduras]]
{{small|(now [[Belize]])}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|10|22|1928|1|26|df=y}} | death_place = Punta Gorda, Belize | instrument = Guitar | genre = [[Garifuna music]] | occupation = Musician | years_active = 1946–2013 | label = | associated_acts = The Garifuna Collective | website = }} '''Paul Nabor''' (26 January 1928 – 22 October 2014), born '''Alfonso Palacio''', was a [[Garifuna people|Garifuna]] singer and musician from [[Punta Gorda, Belize|Punta Gorda]], [[Belize]].{{cite web|title=Priest and Poet: Paul Nabor|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/belize/nabor.html|work=Belize – The Exile's Song|publisher=PBS Frontline|accessdate=1 June 2013|date=January 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040123000856/http://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/belize/nabor.html|archivedate=23 January 2004}} He is often credited with popularizing [[Paranda (music)|paranda]], a style of traditional [[Garifuna music]], and is considered to have been one of the most talented musicians of the genre.{{cite news|last1=Cayetano|first1=Isani|title=Paranda King Paul Nabor Passes|url=http://edition.channel5belize.com/archives/105391|accessdate=25 October 2014|work=News 5|publisher=Great Belize Television|date=October 23, 2014}} ==Early life== Nabor was born on 26 January 1928 (some sources say 1930). Although official sources list his place of birth as [[Dangriga|Stann Creek Town]] (now Dangriga), Nabor told ''[[Amandala]]'' in 2009 that he was born in Punta Gorda, where he was a lifelong resident. Nabor began singing professionally at 18.Ramos, Adele. [http://amandala.com.bz/news/legendary-garifuna-parandero-paul-nabor-passes-86/ "Legendary Garifuna parandero, Paul Nabor, passes at 86"]. ''[[Amandala]]'', 24 October 2014. (accessed 22 May 2015) ==Career== In Belize, Nabor's best known song was "Naguya Nei," which he wrote in memory of his deceased sister. Fluent in [[English language|English]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Garifuna language|Garifuna]], Nabor was a popular entertainer throughout Central America. Nabor performed on [[Andy Palacio]]'s final album, ''Wátina'', released in 2007.[http://www.bordeauxsalsa.com/index.php?theme=MUSIQUE&album=Watina&artiste=Andy%20Palacio&genre=tropical Andy Palacio: ''Watina'' (2007)] at Bordeaux Salsa. Nabor's music is also included on the showcase album ''[[Paranda (album)|Paranda]]'' on [[Stonetree Records]]. He retired from performing full-time in 2009, but played occasionally until 2013. ==Honours== On a 2004 visit to [[Tegucigalpa]], [[Honduras]], he was declared a distinguished guest of the city. Nabor was visiting Tegucigalpa for the Honduran release of ''Garifuna Soul'', an album by fellow paranda musician, [[Aurelio Martinez]].{{cite web|title=Belizean Parandero Receives Award As Hondurans Get Garifuna Soul|url=http://www.stonetreerecords.com/news/2004_paul_nabor_awarded.php|publisher=Stonetree Records|accessdate=1 June 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717095944/http://www.stonetreerecords.com/news/2004_paul_nabor_awarded.php|archivedate=17 July 2012}} ==Death== On 22 October 2014, Nabor died at Punta Gorda Hospital, following a [[stroke]] the week before. He is buried at Mount Olivet Cemetery in Punta Gorda.{{cite news|last1=Ali|first1=Marion|title=Paul Nabor laid to rest at the Mount Olivet Cemetery in Punta Gorda|url=http://www.reporter.bz/general/paul-nabor-laid-to-rest-at-the-mount-olivet-cemetery-in-punta-gorda/|accessdate=2 November 2014|work=The Reporter|date=1 November 2014}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nabor, Paul}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:People from Punta Gorda]] [[Category:Belizean musicians]] [[Category:Garifuna people]] [[Category:Belizean composers]] [[Category:Male composers]] {{Belize-bio-stub}} {{composer-stub}}

{{Infobox officeholder |image = Rudolf_V._Perina,_official_portrait,1998.jpg |office = |president = |term_start = |term_end = |predecessor = |successor = |office1 = |president1 = |term_start1 = |term_end1 = |predecessor1 = |successor1 = |office2 = |president2 = |term_start2 = |term_end2 = |predecessor2 = |successor2 = |birth_date = {{birth date|1945|1|3}} |birth_place = [[Tábor]], [[Czechoslovakia]] (now the [[Czech Republic]]) |death_date = {{death date and age|2018|6|14|1945|1|3}} |death_place = |spouse = {{marriage|Ethel Ott Hetherington
|1972||reason=}} |children = Kaja
Alexandra |alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]]
[[Columbia University]] }} '''Rudolf Vilem Perina''' ({{lang-cs|Rudolf Vilém Peřina}}) (January 3, 1945 – June 14, 2018) was an American [[diplomat]] who specialized for more than three decades in European [[East-West relations]] during and after the [[Cold War]], and on the [[Dayton Accords]] following the dissolution of the [[Former Republic of Yugoslavia]]. This includes working the [[Moscow Summit (1988)|1988 Moscow summit meeting]] between [[President Reagan]] and [[President of the Soviet Union|President]] [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], during the former's first visit to the [[USSR]]. He also served as [[ambassador]] to the [[Republic of Moldova]], U.S. Special Negotiator for Eurasian Conflicts in the [[former Soviet Union]] (an ambassador-level position), Deputy Assistant Secretary for European and Canadian Affairs in the [[State Department]], director of European and Soviet Affairs for the [[U.S. National Security Council]], and was on the policy planning staff of the State Department under [[Colin Powell]] before and after the [[invasion of Iraq]]. Following his retirement from the [[foreign service]], Perina served as [[Chargé d’Affaires]] at [[U.S. embassies]] including those in [[Chisinau]], [[Moldova]] (2006), [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]] (2007), [[Reykjavik]] (2010), [[Prague]] (2013), and [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]] (2015). ==Early life and family== Perina was born on January 3, 1945 in the [[town]] of [[Tábor]] in what is today the [[Czech Republic]]. His father's family owned a large [[lumbermill]] serving [[Central Europe]]. His mother's family was subject to [[Nazi]] [[reprisal]]s during [[World War II]], including the execution of his grandfather and great uncle on June 10, 1942. The family members were executed in a coordinated [[purge]] of Czech nationalists and [[public figure]]s that culminated in the [[razing]] of the town of [[Lidice]]. Perina and his parents fled [[Czechoslovakia]] following the [[1948 Czechoslovak coup d'état|1948 Communist takeover of the government]]. Rudolf's mother paid a [[Croat]] border smuggler to transport her son in January 1950 to the border into [[Austria]] and eventually to [[Zurich]] where his father had escaped. The family lived as [[refugee]]s in [[Switzerland]] and [[Morocco]] before [[immigrating]] to the [[United States]] via [[Le Havre, France]] in 1951. He grew up speaking [[Czech language|Czech]] at home. In 1955, the family moved to [[Cleveland]] and Perina obtained [[US citizenship]] the following year. ==Education== After the family moved to [[Seattle]], Perina attended [[Franklin High School (Seattle)|Franklin High School]] where he made [[valedictorian]] in 1963. He chose the [[University of Chicago]] as it offered him full tuition with a [[stipend]]. He earned his [[B.A.]] degree in [[history]] there in 1967 and did his graduate studies at [[Columbia University]] where he received his [[M.A.]] and [[Ph.D.]] degrees in [[European history]], with the idea of going into academia. While studying in [[New York City|New York]], he was hired by a [[film production]] company to consult and interpret for the filming of a [[documentary]] about the [[Prague Spring|1968 reform movement in Czechoslovakia]] known as the “Prague Spring.” This led to the topic of his Ph.D [[dissertation]]: “Intellectuals and Political Change in Czechoslovakia: A History of Literarni noviny and its Contributors, 1952-1969.”{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Intellectuals_and_Political_Change_in_Cz.html?id=UZhFswEACAAJ|title=Intellectuals and Political Change in Czechoslovakia: A History of Literární Noviny and Its Contributors, 1952-1969|first=Rudolf Vilem|last=Perina|date=29 June 1980|publisher=University Microfilms|via=Google Books}} He had also earned a Foreign Area Fellowhip to research his dissertation at the library of [[Radio Free Europe]] for two years. Perina was at Columbia during the 1968 [[student protest]]s. While supportive of the US [[civil rights movement]] and against the [[Vietnam War]], he maintained a [[moderate]] political position, saying later "I became suspicious of all political extremism and radicalism, whether right-wing or left-wing. It is a position I have held all of my life." ==Career== Returning from Europe to finish his dissertation, Perina found that there were few academic jobs available in the U.S. He saw an ad for the [[foreign service exam]] and encouraged by the example of foreign-born [[Henry Kissinger]], he took it and passed. Delighted to find that it paid better than any academic job, he started in November 1974, his first posting at the U.S. Embassy in [[Ottawa, Canada]] through 1976 during which time both of his daughters were born. At this post, Perina gave [[Russian people|Russian]] author [[Alexander Solzhenitsyn]] his first [[US visa]], whereby he communicated to him in [[German language|German]]. (Already fluent in [[Czech language|Czech]] and [[French language|French]], Perina became fluent in [[Russian language|Russian]] later.) He found that the author of ''[[One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich]]'' and other works "took the process more seriously than almost any other applicant" he had processed up to that time. In reflecting on Solzhenitsyn's conscientiousness later, Perina concluded that "if you spend your life fighting a bureaucracy, your first thought is to not make a mistake in an official document that the bureaucracy can use against you." At Ottawa, Perina also had responsibilities in the [[Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe| Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE)]] whose [[Helsinki Final Act]] was signed by the 35 participating states in the summer of 1975. ===Moscow=== He was then posted to [[Moscow]], and was there during the [[Soviet invasion of Afghanistan]]. Upon witnessing the confrontation with 1st Deputy Foreign Minister [[Georgy Korniyenko]], he said later he was "shown for the first time how unashamedly people can lie in diplomacy." The US response to the invasion was tough, and included suspending exchanges, diplomatic social events, wheat sales, and eventually boycotting the [[Moscow Olympics]], bringing [[Africa]], the [[Middle East]], [[Latin America]], and part of [[Eastern Europe]] along as well. Of the time, Perina has said, "our relations with the Soviets there were very competitive. We were always watching what they did, and they watched us." Although compared to average Soviet citizen, he lived better, Perina has described that life in the Soviet capital "could be difficult." During the harsh winters, he had to remove his [[car battery]] each night to prevent its freezing. The Perinas also saw firsthand the [[psychological warfare]] the [[KGB]] enacted on US embassy personnel, Perina describing his wife Ethel's coat disappearing for several months then reappearing in their closet. ===West Berlin=== He then started to work at the U.S. Mission in [[West Berlin]] in 1981. The US saw [[East Berlin]] differently from the [[GDR]]. Considered a Soviet zone, the Americans maintained another embassy in East Berlin, and the mission in West Berlin avoided dealing with the East Germans by going to the Soviets for things related to them. (The Soviets on the other hand respected the city as part of the GDR and the capital of East Germany.) Perina also described that in Berlin in 1981 it was so easy for the four occupying powers, which included the [[UK]] and [[France]], plus East and West Germany, to [[spy]] on each other being in such close proximities that "the city with more espionage going on per square mile than any other city in Europe." He said that "There was alot of [[eavesdropping]]." As liaison with the Soviets on Russian matters, Perina said that "Nobody seriously thought there was going to be a World War III or an invasion of Berlin by the Warsaw Pact." The diplomat also never got the sense things were loosening up in the USSR. Although he personally did not know whether the [[Strategic Defense Initiative|Strategic Defense Initiative system (SDIs)]] would even work, he understood that the Soviets were threatened by the possibility: He said, "They realized their strength as a world power came from possession of nuclear weapons, and not from their [[GDP]] or anything else." (There was talk too in Germany about [[NATO]] deployment of immediate range nuclear missiles.) Perina served as [[interpreter]] between ambassadors [[Arthur Burns]] and [[Peter Abrassimov|Piotr Abrassimov]], then [[Vyacheslav Kochemasov]] during their twice yearly social lunches. There was bureaucratic protocol too that had to be observed whenever the West German president came to Berlin—the US, French, and British embassies had to greet him formally—which Perina described as a "real nuisance." He also witnessed the tensions in [[Poland]]: The country was moving toward [[martial law]], and Perina describes that by the end of his time there, he and his colleagues were witnessing six or seven Polish [[Aircraft hijacking|plane hijacking]] to West Berlin a year. He also saw the rivalry between the two Germanies, but felt the real threat at the time was from [[radical group]]s like the [[Baader-Meinhof gang]]. {{quotebox|width=450px|align=right|1=Russia was ... a basketcase. The standard of living had declined even from Soviet times. The Russian people had made enormous sacrifices to get rid of Communism and were really hoping for help and partnership with the West. The NATO expansion made them think that the reverse was happening--that their weakness was being exploited. And Russian nationalists and demagogues came forward to take advantage of this perception.— Rudolf V. Perina}} ===Brussels & the 1988 Moscow Summit=== Perina then worked at the U.S. Mission to NATO in [[Brussels]] from 1985, as political officer and deputy US representative to the organization's political committee. The group was handling three simultaneous negotiations, on [[START I#Negotiations|Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START)]], [[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty|Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty (INF)]], and SDIs for a number of visits by [[President Reagan]] to the [[North Atlantic Council]], according to Perina, "the most comprehensive arms control discussion between the US and the Soviet Union." The diplomat's impression of NATO was that it was an American-run organization, with the allies all deferring to the US. From 1987 to 1989, Perina was director for European and Soviet Affairs on the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] staff: prior to his arrival there had been a purge from the [[Iran Contra scandal]]. He was brought in by [[Colin Powell]] who'd been hired by new National Security Council Advisor [[Frank Carlucci]] who ran the department differently, and better, in Perina's opinion. Perina had the Soviet portfolio, which included working on Reagan's [[Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!|"Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall" speech]]. Yet even with this, the Czech-American had no suspicion that the empire was on the verge of collapse, saying "it was not even part of any discussion.... We were all watching the top, the Kremlin .... [W]e did not pay enough attention to the internal situation and particularly to the nationality issues." In preparation for the 1988 meeting between the two world leaders, Perina asked the [[CIA]] to make a film for Reagan about the Moscow sites the president would be visiting and organized a lunch for him with Soviet experts in the US: It would be Reagan's first visit to the USSR. Perina attended the [[Moscow Summit (1988)|1988 Moscow summit meeting]] between Presidents Reagan and [[Mikhail Gorbachev|Gorbachev]], the third of only four total people; he later described the tension between the two principals being rooted in different negotiating styles: The Soviet's being [[deductive]] and the American's [[Inductive reasoning|inductive]]. And although he found the American president very gracious, Perina found the leader of the USSR the more important historical figure "among the most important of our time." He described the former Hollywood actor as having "good instincts" but that he "clearly did not have the grasp of substance that Gorbachev had." Perina believed the summit was significant symbolically, that it influenced Reagan, the Russian people's opinion on Reagan, and changed the dynamics of the US-Russia relationship. Perina was also in charge of the NSC's Eastern European portfolio and visited [[Romania]] under [[Nikolai Ceausescu]]. He described it as a "desperate place" where there was no heat or electricity, and hardly any food in its stores. He said he could see clearly "the fear everyone so clearly had in their eyes," even those around the Rleader himself. Perina left the NSC in spring 1989 when [[George H. W. Bush|President Bush]] and [[Brent Scowcroft]] instituted a complete shift in personnel for political reasons. ===Vienna, Belgrade & the Dayton Accord=== From 1989 to 1992, Perina was deputy chairman of the U.S. Delegation to the [[Vienna]] negotiations on [[Vienna Document|Confidence and Security Building Measures in Europe (CSBM)]], held under auspices of the [[Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe|Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)]]. From 1993 to 1996, he was Chief of Mission at the U.S. Embassy in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] with the title of Charge d’Affaires and worked with a downsized staff. The country was under [[UN]] [[Economic sanctions|sanctions]], and extreme [[inflation]] had forced the country to depend on the [[black market]]. Embassy matters were all handled on a [[cash]] basis: Perina describes having tens of thousands of dollars driven in from [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] in an unguarded car so as not to arouse suspicion from the gangs who then ruled the streets. Perina worked with [[Richard Holbrooke]] as liaison to [[Serbian President]] [[Slobodan Milosevic]] during the negotiations to end the [[Yugoslav Wars|Yugoslav conflict]]. (Some considered Holbrooke's work to have merited the Nobel Peace Prize later.{{cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/holbrooke-trenches-69117|title=World: Holbrooke in the Trenches|date=14 December 2010|last=Moreau|first=Ron}}) They had a dozen meetings with the Serbian ruler with others around, then met him one on one because they found him more engaging in that capacity. Perina saw a "genuine lack of compassion that was truly frightening" and said that this feeling extended to his treatment of his countrymen, the Serbs. Perina also participated in the talks held in [[Dayton, Ohio]], to which he credits Milosevic's assent, although mostly for self-serving purposes: The leader thought he would gain respectability in the international community and sanctions would be lifted. Perina also met with [[Ibrahim Rugova]], the elected president of the [[Republic of Kosovo]], whom along with [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]'s [[Kiro Gligorov]] Perina found to be the most impressive leaders in the former Yugoslavia. {{quotebox|width=450px|align=right|1=Milosevic could agree to the terms of the Dayton Agreement because he was not really a Serb nationalist. He did not care that much about Serbs. He cared about Milosevic. He thought that by helping to conclude an agreement at Dayton his past actions would be forgotten and he would gain legitimacy and respect. But he was wrong. Kosovo was still outstanding, and it would prove to be his downfall.
 — Rudolf V. Perina}} Perina served as Senior Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs;{{cite web|url=https://www.govexec.com/federal-news/1998/04/comings-and-goings/2731/|last=Friel|first=Brian|title=Comings and Goings|publisher=GovExec.com|date=29 April 1998}} in 1996-97 the majority of his time was spent helping to execute the Dayton Accords from [[Washington DC]] while [[John Kornblum]] travelled to implement them. This included the outer wall of sanctions that enraged the Serbs and did not satisfy [[Kosovar Albanian]]s (They would form the [[Kosovo Liberation Army]].) As the former USSR was now handled by the Office of [[Newly Independent States|Newly Independent States (NIS)]] and not the European bureau, the other third of Perina's time was spent on helping to expand NATO, which he said he felt [[ambivalence]] towards: The powerful organization did not help integrate the Russians into Europe and damaged the US's relationship to Russia. He has said "I fear the way we handled revanchism made it a self-fulfulling prophecy." He saw and was shocked by [[Sarajevo]] at the end of the war, which described as "miles and miles of just rubble." Perina has said European and Canadian Affairs was one of his least favorite because it was so bureaucratic and based in the US capital. ===Moldova === Perina was assigned and confirmed ambassadorship to the Republic of Moldova, serving from 1998 to 2001. He studied [[Romanian language|Romanian]] and reviewed his Russian before starting and found the former Soviet republic "a much more pleasant place" than he had imagined: "The people were extremely friendly and hospitable, and the country was a very interesting place to work." His job was to help it develop into a successful, [[autonomous]] nation. It was one of the earliest to [[privatize]] land, helped by a major [[USAID]] project that completed under Perina: The US gave{{cite news|url=http://www.moldova.org/en/petr-lucinschis-meeting-with-rudolf-perina-16814-eng/|title=Petr Lucinschi’s meeting with Rudolf Perina|publisher=Moldova.org}} over $50 million in assistance, the third highest amount given to a former Soviet republic, because of its cooperation and its efforts at [[reform]]. Several hundred Moldovans were sent to the US every year on [[exchange program]]s; Perina was also particularly proud of the [[Peace Corps]] contingent he saw there. Moldava was a main source of the trafficking of women from the former Soviet Union: Many young women were lured into the trade with promises of jobs as [[nannies]] and waitresses in Western Europe, [[the Balkans]] and the [[Middle East]]. The embassy tried to combat this with educational programs and financing a documentary film with victim testimonies that were shown in schools, on billboards and on national TV. He was in Moldova during the [[Transnistria|Transnistrian conflict]], and though the US was not one of the three official mediators (those being Russia, the [[Ukraine]], and the OSCE), the heads of the OSCE mission were American because the Moldovan government wanted to counterbalance their former rulers. Regardless, Perina met with Moldovan Presidents [[Petru Lucinschi]] then [[Vladimir Voronin]] on policy toward Transnistria, even initiating dialogue with the breakaway eastern region's so-called president, [[Igor Smirnov]]. Perina describes these half dozen talks with Smirnov as disheartening. This is because the disputed region had become a staging area for [[smuggling]] operations that avoided taxes and [[customs duties]]. [[People of Ukraine|Ukrainians]] and Moldavans alike profited off the illegal importation of cigarettes, liquor, and "many other commodities" that hurt the republic in lost [[tax revenue]]. Another problem was the 40,000 tons of aging Soviet [[ammunition]] stored at Cosbasna base in Transnistria: The US was a major contributor of several million dollars to a voluntary OSCE fund to aid in arms withdrawal and though there was a limited destruction of tanks and a half trainload of weapons and ammunition, Russian troops and old but still dangerous armaments were kept in the region for political leverage. The economic conflict of the region was also rooted in a lot of Moldava's industry being located in Transnistria,{{cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2008/05/05/the-countertraffickers|title=The Countertraffickers: Rescuing the victims of the global sex trade|last=Finnegan|first=William|date=5 May 2008|publisher=The New Yorker}} planned by [[Stalin]]. === Nagorno-Karabakh & three other former Soviet territories with conflicts=== Perina became the U.S. Special Negotiator for Nagorno-Karabakh and Eurasian Conflicts from 2001, flying out on September 23 when the US airports were reopened after [[9/11]]. The ambassador-level job was Washington D.C.-based but involved a great deal of travel: He was the lead U.S. representative to international efforts to resolve four conflicts in territories of the former Soviet Union: Transnistria, [[Nagorno-Karabakh conflict|Nagorno-Karabakh]], [[Abkhaz–Georgian conflict|Abkhazia]], and [[South Ossetia]] ([[Chechnya]] was the fifth former territory that also had strife but Russia did not let outside influence on it). '''The Nagorno-Karabakh conflict''' had roots in the 1990s war between Armenia and [[Azerbaijan]]: Perina called it a "true indigenous conflict" between the two countries. The OSCE and its specially created [[Minsk Group]] handled the crisis, with many proposals by the latter rejected by both nations, represented by Presidents [[Robert Kocharyan|Kocharyan]] and [[Heydar Aliyev|Aliyev]] respectively, over the years. The first meeting of what came to be known as the [[Prague Process (Armenian–Azerbaijani negotiations)|Prague Process]] took place outside the capital at Stirin Palace in mid-May 2002, a location that Perina helped arranged for. During the US diplomat's tenure through 2004, it remained a stalemated conflict lacking [[peacekeeping]] troops to maintain the separation between the sides with a few soldiers on both sides killed monthly by [[sniper]] fire. Perina 's 2002 idea of a [[referendum]] became the major consideration by 2004: The idea being that residents of Nagorno-Karabakh before hostilities would be able to vote, using lists from the Soviet era. With the intransigence of the two sides, in the end, the conflict was frozen; Perina said of it "the most you can hope for is stabilizing this conflict rather than really resolving it." {{quotebox|width=450px|align=right|1=Sometimes freezing a conflict under agreed terms can be a way of resolving it, for all practical purposes.
 — Rudolf V. Perina}} The Abkhaz were an ethnic minority who participating in the ethnic cleansing of several hundred thousand Georgians in the 1990s with the help of Russians and Chechens. There were 200,000 refugees that resulted. In Perina's view, "The hatred between [the two groups] was the worst I had ever seen in either the Balkans of the Caucauses" calling it "even greater than that between the Serbs and the Albanians." The negotiating process over '''Abkhazia''' stalled but its very existence reduced pressure on the Georgian side for military action against it. '''The hostility in South Ossetia''' was a result of the succession by an ethnic group in Georgia that didn't want to be a part of an independent Georgia, didn't accept its [[sovereignty]], and was protected in this by Russia. The disaccord, per Perina, nevertheless the most promising of the conflicts as the "hatred was not as deep." He felt that most of the population would have welcomed a settlement. The EU was interested in aiding but the Russians blocked them. Perina kept working on the '''Transnistria''' in [[ex-officio]] capacity as the US was not one of the designated mediators. A mandate to resolve this conflict would have institutionalized Russia's presence in Moldava. Deputy Prime Minister of the [[Russian federation]] [[Dmitry Kozak]] attempted to head off the involvement of other countries by arranging for their own settlement for Vladmir Voronin to sign, giving Transnistria de facto veto power over big Moldavan policy decisions. When the Moldavans got wind of the memorandum, 50,000 demonstrated in its capital.
